An '''anatopism''' (from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] ἀνά, "against," and τόπος, "place") is something that is out of its proper place. Thus, for example, an [[outrigger canoe]] would be an anatopism in [[Madrid]].
The [[concept]] of anatopism is less widely familiar than that of [[anachronism]], perhaps because much that is anatopistic is also anachronistic. Yet the distinction is a valid one; not all that is anatopistic is necessarily also anachronistic.
The online ''[[Collins English Dictionary]]'' gives a [[synonym]] for "anatopism": ''anachorism'' (from [[Greek language|Greek]]: ''ana-'' + ''khōros'', "place"): "a geographical misplacement; something located in an incongruent position".<ref>https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/anachorism).</ref>
==Examples== [[Catherine Hardwicke]]'s 2006 film ''[[The Nativity Story]]'' shows a field of [[maize]] in a [[Nazareth]] farming scene. Maize is native to [[Mesoamerica]], not to the [[Middle East]], and in [[pre-Columbian]] times was grown only in the [[Americas]]. The use of maize in this film is an anatopism as well as an anachronism.
The same anatopism appears in the first part ("The Warrior Pharaohs") of a three-part 2002 [[PBS]] documentary series on "Egypt's Golden Empire" depicting the history of [[ancient Egypt]]'s [[New Kingdom of Egypt|New Kingdom]]: ears of [[maize]] corn are shown in a scene recreating the [[Battle of Megiddo (15th century BC)|battle and siege of Megiddo]] in the 15th century BCE.
[[Ridley Scott]]'s 2000 film, ''[[Gladiator (2000 film)|Gladiator]]'', set in 180 CE, features Roman soldiers riding horses using [[saddle]]s with [[stirrup]]s. While the Romans had had saddles since about 100 BCE, and stirrups had existed in the world since about 700 BCE, stirrups did not appear in Europe until about the 6th or 7th century CE, making them both anatopic and anachronistic.
[[John Ford]]'s much-lauded 1939 film [[Stagecoach (1939 film)|''Stagecoach'']] was filmed in [[Monument Valley]] on the [[Arizona]]-[[Utah]] border, but textually set in southern Arizona and southern [[New Mexico]]. The vegetation and topography of Monument Valley and the lower-altitude deserts are vastly different, rendering the film's actual location notably anatopic.
The [[Poland|Polish]] writer [[Bolesław Prus]], for the sake of making a point, introduces into chapter 63 of his [[historical novel]] ''[[Pharaoh (novel)|Pharaoh]]'', set in the [[ancient Egypt]] of 1087–1085 BCE, a substance that behaves like [[gunpowder]].<ref>[[Bolesław Prus]], ''[[Pharaoh (novel)|Pharaoh]]'', pp. 579-81.</ref> This appears to be both an anachronism and an anatopism, since gunpowder is thought to have been invented, some time later, in [[China]] or in [[Arab world|Arabia]]. Another apparent anatopism introduced by the author (in chapter 45) is an object that resembles a [[telescope]],<ref>[[Bolesław Prus]], ''[[Pharaoh (novel)|Pharaoh]]'', p. 391.</ref> that may also be an [[anachronism]].
==See also== * [[Anachronism]] * [[Parachronism]]
==Notes== {{reflist|1}}
==References== *[[Bolesław Prus]], ''[[Pharaoh (novel)|Pharaoh]]'', translated from the [[Polish language|Polish]] by [[Christopher Kasparek]], Warsaw, Polestar Publications, and New York, [[Hippocrene Books]], 2001, {{ISBN|83-88177-01-X}}.

{{Infobox unit | name = Arpent (Parisian) | standard = [[French units of measurement|French]] | quantity = [[length]] | units1 = [[SI units]] | inunits1 = {{val|71.46466|ul=m}} | units2 = [[imperial units|imperial]]/[[US customary units|US]] units | inunits2 = {{convert|71.46466|m|yd|disp=out|lk=on|comma=gaps}}
 {{convert|71.46466|m|ft|disp=out|lk=on|comma=gaps}} }} {{Infobox unit | name = Arpent (North American) | standard = French | quantity = length | units1 = SI units | inunits1 = {{val|58.47131|u=m}} | units2 = imperial/US units | inunits2 = {{convert|58.47131|m|yd|disp=out|comma=gaps}}
 {{convert|58.47131|m|ft|disp=out|comma=gaps}} }} An '''arpent''' ({{IPA-fr|aʁpɑ̃}}) is a unit of [[length]] and a unit of [[area]]. It is a pre-[[Metric system|metric]] [[French units of measurement|French unit]] based on the Roman [[Ancient Roman units of measurement#Length|''actus'']]. It is used in [[Quebec]], some areas of the [[United States customary units|United States]] that were part of [[Louisiana (New France)|French Louisiana]], and in [[Mauritius]] and the [[Seychelles]]. ==Etymology== The word ''arpent'' is believed to derive from the [[Late Latin]] ''arepennis'' (equal to half a ''[[jugerum]]''), which in turn comes from the [[Gaulish]] *''are-penno''- ("end, extremity of a field"). ==Unit of length== There were various standard arpents. The most common were the arpent used in North America, which was defined as 180 [[Units of measurement in France before the French Revolution#Length|French feet]] (''{{lang|fr|pied}}'', of approximately {{convert|32.48|cm|in|disp=or}}), and the arpent used in Paris, which was defined as 220 French feet. * In North America, 1 arpent = 180 French feet = about 192 [[English foot|English feet]] = about 58.47 [[metre]]s * In Paris, 1 arpent = 220 French feet = about 234 English feet = about 71.46 metres ==Unit of area== Historically, in North America, 1 (square) arpent (''{{lang|fr|arpent carré}}''), also known as a French acre, was 180 French feet × 180 French feet = 32,400 French square feet = about 3419 [[square metre]]s = about 0.845 English [[acre]]s. Certain U.S. states have official definitions of the arpent which vary slightly: * In [[Louisiana]], [[Mississippi]], [[Alabama]], and [[Florida]], the official conversion is 1 arpent = {{convert|0.84628|acre|m2|abbr=off}}.In Louisiana, an arpent is equal to approximately 0.84628 acre; see ''Derouen v. Poirier'', 136 So. 2d 131, footnote 1 (La. 3d Cir. Ct. App. 1961) (''dicta''). * In [[Arkansas]] and [[Missouri]], the official conversion is 1 arpent = {{convert|0.8507|acre|m2|abbr=off}}.{{citation|title=Glossary of Geology|editor1=Julia A. Jackson |editor2=James P. Mehl |editor3=Klaus K. E. Neuendorf |publisher=Springer|year=2005|isbn=9780922152766|page=37|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SfnSesBc-RgC&pg=PA37}}. In Paris, the square arpent was 220 French feet × 220 French feet = 48,400 French square feet, about {{convert|5107|m2|acre|disp=or}}. In Mauritius and Seychelles, an arpent is about 4220.87 [[square metre]]s, 0.4221 hectares, 1.043 acres.{{cite book|title=Mauritius: Selected Issues and Statistical Appendix|publisher=International Monetary Fund|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=wqUP-8z25CoC&pg=PA39&lpg=PA39&dq=mauritius+arpent&source=bl&ots=Q5ME0mHg9h&sig=Q6Npl1Drm-w208E2RC_Y6jm6d_g&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj9uIKjvYPWAhUHz2MKHcw9ApYQ6AEIWTAJ#v=onepage&q=mauritius%20arpent&f=false}} ==Louisiana== In Louisiana, parcels of land known as ''arpent'' sections or French ''arpent'' land grants also pre-date the [[Public Land Survey System]] (PLSS), but are treated as PLSS sections. An ''arpent'' is a French measurement of approximately {{convert|192|ft|m}}, and a square arpent (also referred to as an ''arpent'') is about {{convert|0.84|acre|m2}}. French arpent land divisions are long narrow parcels of land, also called [[ribbon farm|ribbon farms]], usually found along the navigable streams of southern Louisiana, and also found along major waterways in other areas. This system of land subdivision was begun by French settlers in the 18th century, according to typical French practice at the time and was continued by both the Spanish and by the American government after the acquisition of the Louisiana Purchase. A typical French arpent land division is 2 to 4 arpents wide along the river by 40 to 60 arpents deep, while the Spanish arpent land divisions tend to be 6 to 8 arpents wide by 40 arpents deep. This method of land division provided each land-owner with river frontage as well as land suitable for cultivation and habitation. These areas are given numbers just like standard sections, although the section numbers frequently exceed the normal upper limit of 36.[http://nationalatlas.gov/articles/boundaries/a_plss.html The Public Land Survey System (PLSS)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511182116/http://nationalatlas.gov/articles/boundaries/a_plss.html |date=2008-05-11 }} ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Acre]] * [[List of unusual units of measurement]] *[[Morgen]] * [[Units of measurement in France before the French Revolution]] * [[Voltaire]] famously dismissed Canada as ''[[Quelques arpents de neige]]'', "a few acres of snow". * [[Weights and Measures Act (R.S. 1985)]] {{div col end}} ==References== [[Category:Units of area]] [[Category:Units of length]] [[Category:Area]] [[Category:Surveying]] [[hu:Hold (mértékegység)]] [[ro:Iugăr]]

{{Infobox waterfall | name = Caracol falls | photo = Caracol Falls.jpg | map = Brazil | map_width = 220 | relief = yes | location = [[Rio Grande do Sul]], [[Brazil]] | coordinates = {{coord|-29.3112|-50.8544|type:landmark_region:BR|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | type = [[waterfall#Types|Plunge]] | height = {{convert|426|ft|m}} | height_longest = {{convert|426|ft|m}} | width = {{convert|115|ft|m}} | watercourse = | average_flow = | world_rank = }} '''Caracol Falls''', or '''Cascata do Caracol''', is a 426-foot (130 meter) [[waterfall]] about {{convert|4.35|mi}} from [[Canela, Rio Grande do Sul|Canela]], [[Brazil]] in [[Caracol State Park]] (''Parque do Caracol'').<ref name="Waggoner">{{Cite book |title= Adventure Guide Brazil |last= Waggoner |first= John |year= 2008 |publisher= Hunter Publishing |location= New Jersey |isbn= 978-1-58843-639-9 |page= 549 }}</ref> It is formed by the [[Caracol River (Rio Grande do Sul)|Caracol River]] and cuts out of [[basalt]] cliffs in the [[Serra Geral]] mountain range, falling into the Vale da Lageana. The falls are situated between the pinheiral (pine forest) zone of the [[Brazilian Highlands]] and the southern coastal [[Atlantic Forest]].<ref>''Tropical Fish Hobbyist'', Vol. 44, p. 188.</ref> The base of the waterfall can be reached by a steep 927-step trail maintained by the Projeto Lobo-Guará.<ref name="Waggoner" />
Waterfall has formed on the basalt rocks of Serra Geral formation and has two cascades. Upper cascade is located approximately 100 m before the second cascade, which falls over an overhanging cliff ledge.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wondermondo.com/Countries/SA/BRA/RioGrandeDoSul/CaracolFalls.htm|title=Caracol Falls|publisher=Wondermondo}}</ref>
Caracol Falls has long attracted visitors and is the second most popular natural tourist attraction in Brazil, trailing only [[Iguazu Falls]]. In 2009, it received more than 289,000 visitors.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Canela flerta com o ecoturismo |author=Paulo Campos |newspaper=Pampulha |date=30 April 2010 |url=http://www.otempo.com.br/jornalpampulha/noticias/?IdNoticia=5817 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> There is a nearby 100-foot observation tower that offers an elevator and a panoramic view, as well as a cable car that gives tourists an aerial view of the waterfall.<ref name="Waggoner" /><ref>{{Cite book |title= Fodor's Brazil |last= Kelly |first= Margaret |year= 2008 |publisher= Fodors Travel Publications |location= New York |isbn= 978-1-4000-1966-3 |page= 281 }}</ref><ref name="Rego">{{Cite book |title= Let's Go Brazil |last= Rego |first= Luis |year= 2004 |publisher= St. Martin's |location= New York |isbn= 978-0-312-32004-1 |page= 268 }}</ref> The area also provides a restaurant and craft stalls.<ref name="Rego" />
==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.world-waterfalls.com/waterfall.php?num=408 Caracol, Cachoeira do | World Waterfall Database: World's Tallest Waterfalls]
==External links== *[http://www.canelaturismo.com.br/roteiros-e-atrativos/parque-do-caracol/ Parque do Caracol page at the Canela Tourism site (Portuguese)]
[[Category:Waterfalls of Brazil]] [[Category:Landforms of Rio Grande do Sul]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Rio Grande do Sul]]

[[File:Hofrat Professor Dr. Karl Diener 1922 J. Harkanyi.png|right|thumb|Carl Diener (1922)]] '''Carl Diener''' (11 December 1862 in [[Vienna]] – 6 January 1928, Vienna) was an Austrian [[geographer]], [[geologist]] and [[paleontologist]].
== Biography == In 1883 he received his doctorate from the [[University of Vienna]], where his instructors included [[Eduard Suess]] and [[Melchior Neumayr]]. In 1893 he changed his [[venia legendi]] from geography to geology, a subject that he became an associate professor of in 1897. In 1906 he was named a full professor of paleontology at the University of Vienna.<ref name=DB>[http://www.deutsche-biographie.de/pnd116103256.html Diener, Carl] Deutsche Biographie</ref>
He is best remembered for his geological (including [[stratigraphy|stratigraphic]]) and faunistic investigations of the [[Alps]]. He also conducted important research on his numerous travels worldwide — [[Syria]] and [[Lebanon]] (1885), the [[Pyrenees]] (1886), the [[Himalayas]] (1892), [[Svalbard]] (1893), the [[Urals]] and the [[Caucasus]] (1897), [[North America]] (1901), et al.<ref name=DB/> In 1895, with [[Wilhelm Heinrich Waagen]], he proposed the [[Anisian Stage]] (a division of the [[Middle Triassic]]) as a replacement for the "Alpine Muschelkalk".<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=v4d0T-L0HaAC&pg=PA10&lpg=PA10&dq=Anisian+Waagen+Diener&source=bl&ots=69fHodeu8D&sig=rEGaEkmh5NG30pTeBjB_-O0Eww0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiTsaKij_3JAhXjj4MKHY5-ABEQ6AEIJDAB#v=onepage&q=Anisian%20Waagen%20Diener&f=false Biostratigraphic Classification of the Marine Triassic in North America] by Norman John Silberling, Edward T. Tozer</ref>
He was an avid mountaineer, and for a number of years was president of the [[Österreichischer Alpenverein]] (Austrian Alpine Club). He was also a member of the [[Alpine Club (UK)|Alpine Club]] in [[London]].<ref name=DB/>
== Published works == With [[Viktor Uhlig]], [[Rudolf Hoernes]] and Eduard Suess, he was co-author of the four-part ''Bau und bild Österreichs'' (1903), of which Diener wrote Part 2: ''Bau und bild der Ostalpen und des Karstgebietes'' (Construction and image of the eastern Alps and the [[karst]] areas).<ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/title/bau-und-bild-osterreichs/oclc/11134829 OCLC WorldCat] Bau und bild Österreichs</ref> He also made major contributions to the paleontological [[bibliography]], ''Fossilium Catalogus'' (1913 –).<ref>[https://de.wikisource.org/wiki/Fossilium_catalogus Fossilium Catalogus] de.Wikisource</ref> Diener's other noteworthy written efforts include: * ''Libanon. Grundlinien der physischen geographie und geologie von Mittel-Syrien'', 1886 – Lebanon: Outlines of physical geography and geology of central Syria. * ''Der Gebirgsbau der Westalpen'', 1891 – The mountain structure of the western Alps. * ''Triadische Cephalopodenfaunen der ostsibirischen Küstenprovinz'', 1895 – Triassic [[cephalopod]]ic fauna of the east [[Siberia]]n coastal region. * ''Mittheilungen über einige Cephalopodensuiten aus der Trias der Südalpen'', 1901 – On some cephalopod groups from the Triassic strata of the southern Alps. * "Triassic faunae of Kashmir", 1913. * ''Paläontologie und Abstammungslehre'', 1920 – Paleontology and [[evolutionary theory]]. * ''Ammonoidea permiana'', 1921 – [[Permian]] [[Ammonoidea]]. * ''Cnidaria triadica'', 1921 – Triassic [[Cnidaria]]. * ''Lamellibranchiata triadica'', 1923 – Triassic [[Lamellibranchiata]]. * ''Grundzüge der Biostratigraphie'', 1925 – Outline of [[biostratigraphy]].<ref>[http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Search/Home?lookfor=%22Diener,Karl,1862-1928.%22&type=author&inst= HathiTrust Digital Library] published works</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
{{authority control}}

{{short description|The maximum population size of the species that the environment can sustain indefinitely}} {{Ecological economics|Concepts}} The '''carrying capacity''' of a biological [[species]] in an [[natural environment|environment]] is the maximum population size of the species that the environment can sustain indefinitely, given the food, [[habitat]], [[drinking water|water]], and other [[Resource|necessities available]] in the environment. In [[population biology]], carrying capacity is defined as the [[environment (biophysical)|environment]]'s maximal load,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hui | first1 = C | year = 2006 | title = Carrying capacity, population equilibrium, and environment's maximal load | url = | journal = Ecological Modelling | volume = 192 | issue = | pages = 317–320 | doi = 10.1016/j.ecolmodel.2005.07.001 }}</ref> which is different from the [[concept]] of population equilibrium. Its effect on [[population dynamics]] may be approximated in a [[logistic function|logistic model]], although this simplification ignores the possibility of [[Overshoot (population)|overshoot]] which real systems may exhibit.
Carrying capacity was originally used to determine the number of animals that could graze on a segment of land without destroying it. Later, the idea was expanded to more complex populations, like humans.<ref>{{cite web|title=Carrying Capacity|url=http://www.sustainablescale.org/ConceptualFramework/UnderstandingScale/MeasuringScale/CarryingCapacity.aspx|website=The Sustainable Scale Project|accessdate=16 February 2017}}</ref> For the [[human population]], more complex variables such as [[sanitation]] and [[Health care|medical care]] are sometimes considered as part of the necessary establishment. As population density increases, [[birth rate]] often increases and [[death rate]] typically decreases. The difference between the birth rate and the death rate is the "natural increase". The carrying capacity could support a positive natural increase or could require a negative natural increase. Thus, the carrying capacity is the number of individuals an environment can support without significant negative impacts to the given organism and its environment. Below carrying capacity, populations typically increase, while above, they typically decrease. A factor that keeps population size at equilibrium is known as a [[regulating factor]]. [[Population decline|Population size decreases]] above carrying capacity due to a range of factors depending on the [[species]] concerned, but can include insufficient [[space]], [[Food security|food supply]], or [[sunlight]]. The carrying capacity of an [[environment (biophysical)|environment]] may vary for different species and may change over time due to a variety of factors including: [[Food security|food availability]], [[water supply]], environmental conditions and living space. The origins of the term "carrying capacity" are uncertain, with researchers variously stating that it was used "in the context of international [[shipping]]"<ref name="informaworld.com">{{cite journal |last1=Sayre |first1=N. F. |year=2008 |title=The Genesis, History, and Limits of Carrying Capacity |journal=Annals of the Association of American Geographers |volume=98 |issue= |pages=120–134 |publisher= |doi= 10.1080/00045600701734356|url=http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~content=a791001773&db=all }}</ref> or that it was first used during 19th-century laboratory experiments with micro-organisms.<ref>Zimmerer, K.S., [http://dusk.geo.orst.edu/prosem/PDFs/human_geog.pdf "Human Geography and the "New Ecology": The Prospect of Promise and Integration"], ''Annals of the Assoc. of American Geo.'', '''84'''(1), 108–125, (1994)</ref> A recent review finds the first use of the term in an 1845 report by the [[US Secretary of State]] to the [[US Senate]].<ref name="informaworld.com"/>
==Humans== {{Contradicts other|date=May 2014|1=Human overpopulation|discuss=Talk:Carrying_capacity#Where_is_the_contradiction.3F}} {{main|Human overpopulation}} Several estimates of the carrying capacity have been made with a wide range of population numbers. A 2001 UN report said that two-thirds of the estimates fall in the range of 4 billion to 16 billion with unspecified standard errors, with a median of about 10 billion.<ref name="UN World Population Report 2001">{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/wpm/wpm2001.pdf|format=PDF|title=UN World Population Report 2001|page=31|accessdate=16 December 2008}}</ref> More recent estimates are much lower, particularly if [[resource depletion|non-renewable resource depletion]] and [[Overconsumption|increased consumption]] are considered.<ref>{{Citation | last = Ryerson | first = W. F. | chapter = Population, The Multiplier of Everything Else | date = | editor-last = McKibben | editor-first = D | title = The Post Carbon Reader: Managing the 21st Centery Sustainability Crisis | publisher = Watershed Media | publication-date = 2010 | isbn = 978-0-9709500-6-2 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last =Brown | first =L. R. | title =World on the Edge | publisher =Norton | series =Earth Policy Institute | year =2011 | pages = | isbn =978-0-393-08029-2 }}</ref> Changes in habitat quality or human behavior at any time might increase or reduce carrying capacity. In the view of [[Paul R. Ehrlich|Paul and Anne Ehrlich]], "for earth as a whole (including those parts of it we call Australia and the United States), human beings are far above carrying capacity today."<ref name=Nineveh-Book/>
The application of the concept of carrying capacity for the [[human population]] has been criticized for not successfully capturing the multi-layered processes between humans and the environment, which have a nature of fluidity and [[non-equilibrium]], and for sometimes being employed in a [[Victim blaming|blame-the-victim]] framework.<ref name=Cliggett>Cliggett, L., "Carrying Capacity's New Guise: Folk Models for Public Debate and Longitudinal Study of Environmental Change", ''[[Africa Today]]'', '''48'''(1), 2-19, (2001)</ref><!-- Although the quote may be good the author doesn't reference anything when making it [http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-80493292/carrying-capacity-new-guise.html 1]-->
Supporters of the concept argue that the idea of a limited carrying capacity is just as valid applied to humans as when applied to any other species. Animal population size, living standards, and resource depletion vary, but the concept of carrying capacity still applies. The number of people is not the only factor in the carrying capacity of Earth. [[Waste]] and [[over-consumption]], especially by wealthy and near-wealthy people and nations, are also putting significant strain on the environment together with [[human overpopulation]]. Population and consumption together appear to be at the core of many human problems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://e360.yale.edu/feature/consumption_dwarfs_population_as_main_environmental_threat/2140/|title=Consumption Dwarfs Population as Main Environmental Threat|date=2009-04-13|publisher=Yale University|author=Fred Pearce|accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref><ref name=Nineveh-Book>{{citation | last1=Ehrlich | first1=Paul R | author-link1=Paul R. Ehrlich | last2=Ehrlich | first2=Anne H | author-link2=Paul R. Ehrlich | title=One with Nineveh: Politics, Consumption, and the Human Future | date=2004 | pages=137, 182, see also pages 76-236 | publisher=Island Press/Shearwater Books }}</ref> Some of these issues have been studied by computer simulation models such as [[World3]]. When scientists talk of global change today, they are usually referring to human-caused changes in the environment of sufficient magnitude eventually to ''reduce'' the carrying capacity of much of Earth (as opposed to local or regional areas) to support organisms, especially ''Homo sapiens.''<ref name=Dominant-Animal-Book>{{citation | last1=Ehrlich | first1=Paul R | author-link1=Paul R. Ehrlich | last2=Ehrlich | first2=Anne H | author-link2=Paul R. Ehrlich | title=The Dominant Animal: Human Evolution and the Environment | date=2008 | pages=235, see also pages 234-309 | publisher=Island Press/Shearwater Books }}</ref>
===Factors that govern carrying capacity=== Some aspects of a system's carrying capacity may involve matters such as available supplies of [[food supply|food]], [[water supply|water]], raw materials, and/or other similar resources. In addition, there are other factors that govern carrying capacity which may be less instinctive or less intuitive in nature, such as ever-increasing and/or ever-accumulating levels of [[waste]]s, [[environmental damage|damage]], and/or eradication of essential components of any complex functioning system. Eradication of, for example, large or critical portions of any [[complex system]] (envision a space vehicle, for instance, or an airplane, or an automobile, or computer code, or the body components of a living vertebrate) can interrupt essential processes and dynamics in ways that induce systems failures or unexpected collapse. (As an example of these latter factors, the "carrying capacity" of a complex system such an airplane is more than a matter of available food, or water, or available seating, but also reflects total weight carried and presumes that its passengers do not damage, destroy, or eradicate parts, [[Door|doors]], windows, wings, engine parts, fuel, and oil, and so forth.) Thus, on a global scale, food and similar resources may affect planetary carrying capacity to some extent so long as Earth's human passengers do not dismantle, eradicate, or otherwise destroy critical [[biosphere|biospheric]] life-support capacities for essential processes of self-maintenance, [[self-perpetuation]], and [[self-repair mechanisms|self-repair]].
Thus, carrying capacity interpretations that focus solely on resource limitations alone (such as food) may neglect wider functional factors. If the humans neither gain nor lose weight in the long-term, the calculation is fairly accurate. If the quantity of food is invariably equal to the "Y" amount, carrying capacity has been reached. Humans, with the need to enhance their reproductive success (see Richard Dawkins' ''[[The Selfish Gene]]''{{Verify source|date=May 2009}}<!-- the gene-centric model of evolution is disputed, in particular in sentient species. Contrast with the Expanded Phenotype, also by Dawkins -->), understand that food supply can vary and also that other factors in the environment can alter humans' need for food. A house, for example, might mean that one does not need to eat as much to stay warm as one otherwise would. Over time, monetary transactions have replaced barter and local production, and consequently modified local human carrying capacity. However, purchases also impact regions thousands of miles away. For example, [[carbon dioxide]] from an [[automobile]] travels to the upper atmosphere. This led [[Paul R. Ehrlich]] to develop the [[I = PAT]] equation.<ref>Ehrlich, P.R., Holdren, J.P., "Impact of Population Growth", [[Science (journal)|''Science'']], '''171'''(3977), 1212–1217, (1971)</ref>
: {{math|1=''I'' = ''P'' ∙ ''A'' ∙ ''T''}} where: : ''I'' is the impact on the environment resulting from consumption : ''P'' is the population number : ''A'' is the consumption per capita (affluence) : ''T'' is the technology factor [[File:Logistic curve examples.png|thumb|This is a graph of the population due to the logistic curve model. When the population is above the carrying capacity it decreases, and when it is below the carrying capacity it increases.]] An important model related to carrying capacity (K), is the logistic, growth curve. The logistic growth curve depicts a more realistic version of how population growth rate, available resources, and the carrying capacity are inter-connected. As illustrated in the logistic growth curve model, when the population size is small and there are many resources available, population over-time increases and so does the growth rate. However, as population size nears the carrying capacity and resources become limited, the growth rate decreases and population starts to level out at K. This model is based on the assumption that carrying capacity does not change. One thing to keep in mind, however, is that carrying capacity of a population can increase or decrease and there are various factors that affect it. For instance, an increase in the population growth can lead to over-exploitation of necessary natural resources and therefore decrease the overall carrying capacity of that environment.<ref>Swafford, Angela Lynn. "Logistic Population Growth: Equation, Definition & Graph." Study.com. N.p., 30 May 2015. Web. 21 May 2016. "Logistic Population Growth - Boundless Open Textbook." Boundless. N.p., n.d. Web. 21 May 2016. </ref>
Technology can play a role in the dynamics of carrying capacity and while this can sometimes be positive,<ref>Martire, S., Castellani, V., & Sala, S. (2015). [https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.resconrec.2014.11.002 Carrying capacity assessment of forest resources: Enhancing environmental sustainability in energy production at local scale] Resources, Conservation and Recycling, 94, 11-20. doi: [https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.resconrec.2014.11.002]</ref> in other cases its influence can be problematic. For example, it has been suggested that in the past that the [[Neolithic]] revolution increased the carrying capacity of the world relative to humans through the invention of agriculture. In a similar way, viewed from the perspective of foods, the use of [[fossil fuel]]s has been alleged to artificially increase the carrying capacity of the world by the use of stored sunlight, even though that food production does not guarantee the capacity of the Earth's climatic and [[Biosphere|biospheric]] life-support systems to withstand the damage and wastes arising from such fossil fuels. However, such interpretations presume the continued and uninterrupted functioning of all other critical components of the global system. It has also been suggested that other technological advances that have increased the carrying capacity of the world relative to humans are: [[polder]]s, [[fertilizer]], [[composting]], [[greenhouse]]s, [[land reclamation]], and [[fish farming]].{{citation needed|date=January 2011}} In an adverse way, however, many technologies enable economic entities and individual humans to inflict far more damage and eradication, far more quickly and efficiently on a wider-scale than ever. Examples include machine guns, chainsaws, earth-movers, and the capacity of industrialized fishing fleets to capture and harvest targeted fish species faster than the fish themselves can reproduce are examples of such problematic outcomes of technology.
[[Agricultural capability]] on Earth expanded in the last quarter of the 20th century. But now there are many projections of a continuation of the decline in world agricultural capability (and hence carrying capacity) which began in the 1990s. Most conspicuously, China's food production is forecast to decline by 37% by the last half of the 21st century, placing a strain on the entire carrying capacity of the world, as China's population could expand to about 1.5 billion people by the year 2050.<ref>Economy, E., ''China vs. Earth'', The Nation, May 7, 2007 issue</ref> This reduction in China's agricultural capability (as in other world regions) is largely due to the world [[water crisis]] and especially due to mining [[groundwater]] beyond sustainable yield, which has been happening in China since the mid-20th century.<ref>Nielsen, R., ''The Little Green Handbook'', [[Picador (imprint)|Picador]], (2006) {{ISBN|978-0-312-42581-4}}</ref>
[[Lester Brown]] of the [[Earth Policy Institute]], has said: "It would take 1.5 Earths to sustain our present level of consumption. Environmentally, the world is in an [[overshoot (population)|overshoot]] mode."<ref>{{cite book | last =Brown | first =L. R. | title =World on the Edge | publisher =Norton | series =Earth Policy Institute | year =2011 | page =7 | isbn =978-0-393-08029-2 }}</ref>
===Ecological footprint=== One way to estimate human [[demand]] compared to ecosystem's carrying capacity is "[[ecological footprint]]" accounting. Rather than speculating about future possibilities and limitations imposed by carrying capacity constraints, Ecological Footprint accounting provides empirical, non-speculative assessments of the past. It compares historic regeneration rates, [[biocapacity]], against historical human [[demand]], [[ecological footprint]], in the same year.<ref name="WS">{{cite journal | last1 = Wackernagel | first1 = M. | last2 = Schulz | first2 = N.B. | display-authors = etal |year=2002 |title="Tracking the ecological overshoot of the human economy |url=http://www.pnas.org/content/99/14/9266.short |journal=[[PNAS|Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA]] | volume = 99 | issue = 14| pages = 9266–9271 | doi=10.1073/pnas.142033699 | pmid=12089326 | pmc=123129| bibcode = 2002PNAS...99.9266W }}</ref><ref>Rees, W.E. and Wackernagel, M., ''Ecological Footprints and Appropriated Carrying Capacity: Measuring the Natural Capital Requirements of the Human Economy'', Jansson, A., Folke, C., Hammer, M. and Costanza R. (ed.), [[Island Press]], (1994)</ref> One result shows that humanity's demand footprint in 1999 exceeded the planet's bio-capacity by >20%.<ref name="WS" /> However, this measurement does not take into account the depletion of the actual fossil fuels, "which would result in a carbon Footprint many hundreds of times higher than the current calculation."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.footprintnetwork.org/en/index.php/GFN/page/frequently_asked_technical_questions/|title=FAQ - Global Footprint Network|author=|date=|website=footprintnetwork.org|accessdate=28 March 2018}}</ref>
There is also concern of the ability of countries around to globe to decrease and maintain their ecological footprints. Holden and Linnerud, scholars working to provide a better framework that adequately judge sustainability development and maintenance in policy making, have generated a diagram that measures the global position of different countries around the world, which shows a linear relation between GDP PPP and ecological foot print in 2007. Possible answers to the question of where we are as individual countries attempting to reach sustainability and development methods to reduce ecological foot print. According to the Figure 1 diagram, the United States had the largest ecological foot print per capita along with Norway, Sweden, and Austria, in comparison to Cuba, Bangladesh, and Korea. <ref name="The Sustainable Development Area">{{cite journal|last1=Holden|first1=Erling|last2=Linnerud|first2=Kristin|title=The sustainable development area: satisfying basic needs and safeguarding ecological sustainability|journal=Sustainable Development|date=May 2007|volume=15|issue=3|pages=174–187|doi=10.1002/sd.313}}</ref>

revision.text:
'''Erodability''' (or '''erodibility''') is the inherent yielding or nonresistance of soils and rocks to [[erosion]]. A high erodability implies that the same amount of work exerted by the [[erosion]] processes leads to a larger removal of material. Because the mechanics behind erosion depend upon the competence and coherence of the material, erodability is treated in different ways depending on the type of surface that eroded.
==Soils== Soil erodibility is a lumped parameter that represents an integrated annual value of the soil profile reaction to the process of soil detachment and transport by raindrops and surface flow.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ars.usda.gov/ARSUserFiles/64080530/rusle/ah_703.pdf|title=Handook of RUSLE|last=Renard|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> The most commonly used model for predicting soil loss from water erosion is the ''[[Universal Soil Loss Equation|Universal Soil Loss Equation (USLE)]]'' (also known as the K-factor technique), which estimates the average annual soil loss <math>A</math> as:<ref>{{cite book|author=Ward, Andrew D.|author2=Trimble, Stanley W.|last-author-amp=yes|chapter=Soil conservation and sediment budgets|title=Environmental Hydrology|publisher=CRC Press|year=2004|isbn=978-1-56670-616-2|page=259|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yANwmTjf588C&pg=PA259}}</ref> :<math>A = R K L S C P</math> where ''R'' is the [https://web.archive.org/web/20150319194419/http://eusoils.jrc.ec.europa.eu/library/themes/erosion/RainfallErosivity/ rainfall erosivity factor], ''K'' is the soil erodibility,<ref>[http://eusoils.jrc.ec.europa.eu/library/themes/erosion/Erodibility/ Soil Erodability (K-Factor) in Europe, European Commission.]</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Panagos|first=Panos|last2=Meusburger|first2=Katrin|last3=Ballabio|first3=Cristiano|last4=Borrelli|first4=Pasqualle|last5=Alewell|first5=Christine|title=Soil erodibility in Europe: A high-resolution dataset based on LUCAS|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0048969714001727|journal=Science of the Total Environment|volume=479-480|pages=189–200|doi=10.1016/j.scitotenv.2014.02.010}}</ref> ''L'' and ''S'' are [[topographic]] factors representing length and slope, and ''C'' and ''P'' are cropping management factors.
Other factors such as the stone content (referred as ''stoniness''), which acts as protection against soil erosion, are very significant in Mediterranean countries.
==Rocks==
===Shear stress model=== Geological and experimental studies have shown that the erosion of bedrock by rivers follows in first approach the following expression<ref>Bagnold, R. A. (1977), Bedload transport by natural rivers, Water Resoure. Res., 13, 303–312, doi:10.1029/WR013i002p00303.</ref> known as the ''shear stress model'' of [[stream power]] erosion: :<math>{dz \over dt} = - K_\tau (\tau\ - \tau\ _c) ^a </math> where ''z'' is the riverbed elevation, ''t'' is time, ''K_\tau'' is the erodability, <math>\tau</math> is the basal shear stress of the water flow, and ''a'' is an exponent. For a river channel with a slope ''S'' and a water depth ''D'', <math>\tau</math> can be expressed as: :<math>\tau\ = \rho\ g D S</math>
Note that ''<math>K_\tau</math>'' embeds not only mechanical properties inherent to the rock but also other factors unaccounted in the previous two equations, such as the availability of river tools (pebbles being dragged by the current) that actually produce the abrasion of the riverbed.
''<math>K_\tau</math>'' can be measured in the lab for weak rocks, but river erosion rates in natural geological scenarios are often slower than 0.1 mm/yr, and therefore the river incision must be dated over periods longer than a few thousand years to make accurate measurements. ''K<sub>e</sub>'' values range between 10<sup>−6</sup> to 10<sup>+2</sup> m yr<sup>−1</sup> Pa<sup>−1.5</sup> for a=1.5 and 10<sup>−4</sup> to 10<sup>+4</sup> m yr<sup>−1</sup> Pa<sup>−1</sup> for a=1.<ref>Garcia-Castellanos, D., A. Villaseñor, 2011. Messinian salinity crisis regulated by competing tectonics and erosion at the Gibraltar Arc. Nature, 480, 359-363, doi:10.1038/nature10651</ref> However, the hydrological conditions in these time scales are usually poorly constrained, impeding a good the quantification of ''D''.
===Unit stream power model=== An alternative model for bedrock erosion is the ''unit stream power'', which assumes that erosion rates are proportional to the potential energy loss of the water per unit area: :<math>{dz \over dt} = - K_\omega\ \omega\ </math> where ''<math>K_\omega</math>'' is the erodability, and <math>\omega</math> is the unit stream power, which is easily calculated as: :<math>\omega\ = \rho\ g Q S / W</math> where ''Q'' is the water discharge of the river [m<sup>3</sup>/s], and ''W'' is the width of the river channel [m].
Relative differences in long-term erodability can be estimated by quantifying the erosion response under similar climatic and topographic conditions with different rock lithology.<ref>Hooke, Rohrer, 1977 - Relative erodibility of source-area rock types, as determined from second-order variations in alluvial-fan size, Geological Society of America Bulletin, v. 88, p. 1177-1182, 4 figs., August 1977, Doc. no. 70815</ref>

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Gps tracking geofence.png|thumb|Geofences in GPS tracking software]] --> [[File:GeoFence.jpg|thumb|Two geofences defined in a GPS application]] A '''geo-fence''' is a [[Virtuality|virtual]] [[perimeter]] for a real-world [[geographic area]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://whatis.techtarget.com/definition/geofencing|title=What is geo-fencing (geofencing)? - Definition from WhatIs.com|newspaper=WhatIs.com|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-10}}</ref> A geo-fence could be dynamically generated—as in a radius around a point location, or a geo-fence can be a predefined set of boundaries (such as school zones or neighborhood boundaries).
The use of a geo-fence is called '''geo-fencing''', and one example of usage involves a location-aware device of a [[location-based service]] (LBS) user entering or exiting a geo-fence. This activity could trigger an alert to the device's user as well as messaging to the geo-fence operator. This info, which could contain the location of the device, could be sent to a [[mobile telephone]] or an email account.
==Applications== Geofencing, used with [[Parental controls|child location]] services, can notify parents if a child leaves a designated area.<ref>{{cite book |title=Location Systems: An Introduction to the Technology Behind Location Awareness |last=De Lara |first=Eyal |author2=Anthony LaMarca |author3=Mahadev Satyanarayanan |year=2008 |publisher=Morgan & Claypool Publishers |isbn=978-1-59829-581-8 |page=88 }}</ref>
Geofencing used with [[locationized firearms]] can restrict those firearms to fire only in locations where their firing is permitted, thereby making them unable to be used elsewhere.
Geofencing is critical to [[telematics]]. It allows users of the system to draw zones around places of work, customer's sites and secure areas. These geo-fences when crossed by an equipped vehicle or person can trigger a warning to the user or operator via SMS or email.
In some companies, geofencing is used by the [[Human resource management|human resource]] department to monitor employees working in special locations especially those doing field works. Using a geofencing tool, an employee is allowed to log his or her attendance using a GPS-enabled device when within a designated perimeter.
Other applications include sending an alert if a vehicle is stolen<ref>{{cite news |title=Motorcycle Tracker Updates Every 15 Seconds |url=http://www.motorcycle-usa.com/2/2304/Motorcycle-Article/Motorcycle-Tracker-Updates-Every-15-Seconds.aspx |work=Motorcycle USA |date=23 January 2009 |accessdate=2009-01-26 }}</ref> and notifying rangers when wildlife stray into farmland.<ref>{{cite news |title=Kenya's elephants send text messages to rangers |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/10/11/tech/main4515365.shtml |work=[[CBS News]] |date=11 February 2009 }} </ref>
Geo-fence can be used for location based messaging for tourist safety and communication.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ugoround.com/white_papers/UgoRound-White-Paper-Location-based-messaging-for-Tourists.pdf |title=Location Based Messaging for Tourist Safety and Communication |publisher=UgoRound.com |date=3 July 2017 |accessdate=21 September 2017}}</ref>
Geofencing, in a security strategy model, provides security to wireless local area networks. This is done by using predefined borders (e.g., an office space with borders established by positioning technology attached to a specially programmed server). The office space becomes an authorized location for designated users and wireless mobile devices.<ref>Hamid Jahankhani, A G Hessami, Feng Hsu: Global security, safety, and sustainability : 5th international conference, ICGS3 2009, London, UK, September 1-2, 2009 : proceedings. {{ISBN|978-3-642-04061-0}}</ref>
One expert in [[global positioning system]] security, and a politician, has suggested that government regulators should encourage drone manufacturers to build geofencing constraints into [[unmanned aerial vehicle]] navigation systems that would override the commands of the unsophisticated operator, preventing the device from flying into protected [[airspace]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Todd Humphreys: Don't Overregulate Drones |url=http://alcalde.texasexes.org/2015/03/todd-humphreys-dont-overregulate-drones/ |work=Alcalde |date=18 March 2015 |accessdate=2015-04-05 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.schumer.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/schumer-proposes-new-law-designed-to-virtually-eliminate-chance-of-drones-crashing-into-planes-geo-fencing-amendment-would-require-software-on-every-drone-that-would-prohibit-flying-near-airports-and-sensitive-areas-the-technology-worksall-thats-needed-is-a-law |last=Schumer |first=Charles |title=Schumer proposes law |date=19 August 2015 |accessdate=15 December 2015}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Assisted GPS]] (A-GPS) *[[Automotive navigation system]] *[[Geomessaging]] *[[Geotagging]] *[[GPS drawing]] *[[GPS tracking]] *''[[Ingress (game)|Ingress]]'' *[[Point in polygon]] *[[Point of interest]] *[[Geomarketing]]

==Further reading== *De Lara, Eyal; Anthony LaMarca, Mahadev Satyanarayanan (2008). ''Location Systems: An Introduction to the Technology Behind Location Awareness.'' Morgan & Claypool Publishers. p. 88. {{ISBN|978-1-59829-581-8}}. *Anthony C. Ijeh, Allan J. Brimicombe, David S. Preston, Chris O. Imafidon (2009) "Geofencing in a Security Strategy Model." In ''Global Safety and Sustainability: 5th International Conference Proceedings''. Jahankhani, H.; Hessami, A.G.; Hsu, F. (Eds.) p.104-111 © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2009. {{ISBN|978-3-642-04061-0}}

[[Image:Matterhorn ascent Dore.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|''The First Ascent of the Matterhorn'', by [[Gustave Doré]]. This ascent, by [[Edward Whymper]] and party in 1865, traditionally marks the end of the golden age of alpinism.]] The '''golden age of alpinism''' was the decade in [[mountaineering]] between [[Alfred Wills]]'s ascent of the [[Wetterhorn]] in 1854<ref>Though Wills thought he had made a first ascent, the Wetterhorn had been climbed in 1844, and his was the fourth ascent. However, mountaineering became fashionable in Britain after the barrister's climb.</ref> and [[Edward Whymper]]'s [[First ascent of the Matterhorn|ascent]] of the [[Matterhorn]] in 1865, during which many major peaks in the [[Alps]] saw their [[first ascent]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/blogs/2010/7/the-matterhorn-edward-whymper-and-the-golden-age-of-mountaineering |title=The Matterhorn: Edward Whymper and the Golden Age of Mountaineering | Britannica Blog |publisher=Britannica.com |date=2010-07-14 |accessdate=2014-03-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I--BAAAAMAAJ&q=%22golden+age+of+alpinism%22+wetterhorn&dq=%22golden+age+of+alpinism%22+wetterhorn&hl=en&ei=uPrPTNuOPI2U4gbDitmPBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA |title=Big wall climbing - Doug K. Scott - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-03-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/1501041.stm |title=EUROPE | Alpine expedition goes online |publisher=BBC News |date=2001-09-04 |accessdate=2014-03-22}}</ref>
==Prominent figures== With its beginning slightly predating the formation of the [[Alpine Club (UK)|Alpine Club]] in London in 1857, the golden age was dominated by British alpinists and their Swiss and French guides. Prominent figures of the period include [[Lord Francis Douglas]], [[Paul Grohmann]], [[Florence Crauford Grove]], [[Charles Hudson (climber)|Charles Hudson]], [[Edward Shirley Kennedy|E. S. Kennedy]], [[William Mathews (mountaineer)|William Mathews]], [[Adolphus Warburton Moore|A. W. Moore]], [[Leslie Stephen]], [[Francis Fox Tuckett]], [[John Tyndall]], [[Horace Walker]] and [[Edward Whymper]]. Well-known guides of the era include [[Christian Almer]], [[Jakob Anderegg]], [[Melchior Anderegg]], {{illm|Johann Joseph Benet|de||es|Johann Joseph Bennen|fr|Johann Joseph Bennen}}, {{illm|Peter Bohren|de||fr|}}, [[Jean-Antoine Carrel]], [[Michel Croz]], {{illm|Ulrich Kaufmann|de|Ulrich Kaufmann (Bergführer)|fr||pt|}} and Johannes Zumtaugwald.
Walker's sister [[Lucy Walker (climber)|Lucy]] also attained some notable firsts during the period, including the first ascent of the [[Balmhorn]] (1864), and later several first female ascents.
In the early years of the "[[golden age]]", scientific pursuits were intermixed with the sport. More often than not, the mountaineers carried a variety of instruments up the mountain with them to be used for scientific observations. The physicist [[John Tyndall]] was the most prominent of the scientists. Among the non-scientist mountaineers, the literary critic [[Leslie Stephen]] was the most prominent. In the later years of the "golden age", the non-scientist pure sportsmen came to dominate the London-based Alpine Club and alpine mountaineering overall.<ref>Claire Eliane Engel (1950), ''A History of Mountaineering in the Alps'', chapter VII.</ref>
== First ascents in the golden age == * 1854 [[Königspitze]], [[Ostspitze|Ostspitze (Monte Rosa)]], [[Strahlhorn]] * 1855 [[Mont Blanc du Tacul]], [[Dufourspitze|Westspitze (Monte Rosa)]], [[Weissmies]] * 1856 [[Aiguille du Midi]], [[Allalinhorn]], [[Lagginhorn]] * 1857 [[Mönch]], [[Monte Pelmo]] * 1858 [[Dom (mountain)|Dom]], [[Eiger]], [[Nadelhorn]], [[Piz Morteratsch]], [[Wildstrubel]] * 1859 [[Aletschhorn]], [[Bietschhorn]], [[Grand Combin]], [[Grivola]], [[Rimpfischhorn]], [[Monte Leone]] * 1860 [[Alphubel]], [[Blüemlisalp]]horn, [[Civetta]], [[Gran Paradiso]], [[Grande Casse]] * 1861 [[Castor (mountain)|Castor]], [[Fluchthorn]], [[Lyskamm]], [[Mont Pourri]], [[Monte Viso]], [[Schreckhorn]], [[Weisshorn]], [[Weißkugel]] * 1862 [[Dent Blanche]], [[Dent Parrachée]], [[Doldenhorn]], [[Fiescherhorn|Gross Fiescherhorn]], [[Monte Disgrazia]], [[Täschhorn]], [[Zuckerhütl]] * 1863 [[Bifertenstock]], [[Dent d'Hérens]], [[Parrotspitze]], [[Piz Zupò]], [[Tofane]] * 1864 [[Mount Adamello|Adamello]], [[Aiguille d'Argentière]], [[Aiguille de Tré la Tête]], [[Antelao]], [[Balmhorn]], [[Barre des Écrins]], [[Dammastock]], [[Gross Wannenhorn]], [[Marmolata]], [[Mont Dolent]], [[Pollux (mountain)|Pollux]], [[Presanella]], [[Zinalrothorn]] * 1865 [[Aiguille Verte]], [[Grand Cornier]], [[La Ruinette]], [[Matterhorn]], [[Ober Gabelhorn]], [[Piz Buin]], [[Piz Roseg]]
{{Expand list|date=August 2008}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox lake | name = Isbladskärret | image = Isbladskärret 11 070607.JPG | caption = The lake, with the Kaknäs Tower in the background | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | coords = {{coord|59|19|36|N|18|8|36|E|region:SE_type:waterbody_scale:10000|display=inline,title}} | type = | inflow = | outflow = | catchment = {{convert|20|ha|abbr=on}} | basin_countries = Sweden | length = | width = | area = {{convert|3.7|ha|abbr=on}} | depth = < {{convert|1|m|abbr=on}} | max-depth = | volume = | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = | islands = | cities = [[Djurgården]] }} '''Isbladskärret''' is a small [[lake]]{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} on [[Djurgården]], an island in central [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]]. The lake is much appreciated among bird-watchers, and, being part of the [[Royal National City Park]], also carefully monitored by several organizations, including the [[World Wide Fund for Nature]]. The lake is one of six in Djurgården (including Northern Djurgården, north of the island), the others being [[Lillsjön, Djurgården|Lillsjön]], [[Uggleviken]], [[Spegeldammen]], [[Lappkärret]], and [[Laduviken]].<ref name="sthlm-vatten">{{cite web|title=Isbladskärret |publisher=Stockholms vatten |date=2004-06-28 |location=Stockholm |url=http://www.stockholmvatten.se/vattenvard/sjoar_vattendrag/pdf/04Isblad.pdf |accessdate=2007-01-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050316085812/http://www.stockholmvatten.se/vattenvard/sjoar_vattendrag/pdf/04Isblad.pdf |archivedate=March 16, 2005 }}</ref>
== Origin of the name == [[File:Isbladskärret 02 070607.JPG|thumb|Old pump on the southern approach to the lake.]] The name is derived from a small hunter's lodge located near the present lake. In historical records documenting fishing grounds on Djurgården during the 17th century, the lodge is unintelligibly called ''Isbla''. The same lodge also gave name to a bay, [[Isbladsviken]]. Most Stockholmer's today are likely to interpret the name as ''Is-blads-kärret'' ("The Ice Leaf Marsh").<ref name="Hasselblad">{{cite book | author = Björn Hasselblad | title = Djurgårdsvandringar på norra och södra Djurgården | edition = 2nd | year = 1990 | publisher = [[Royal Djurgården Administration]] (''Kungliga Djurgårdens förvaltning'') | location = Stockholm | isbn = 978-91-970418-0-5 | pages = 23 | chapter = Södra Djurgården }}</ref>
== History == The area was originally a [[marsh]] separating the northern and southern parts of Djurgården until the 1830s when the canal [[Djurgårdsbrunnskanalen]] was built. By the turn of the century 1900, [[Prince Carl, Duke of Västergötland|Prince Carl]] (1861–1951) settle at [[Parkudden]] nearby and had the swamp drained. The surrounding area was then used for agriculture until the 1950s, but the pumping-station remained in use until the [[Royal Djurgården Administration]] decided to develop the area in 1981 to attracts birds and plant life and closed to pump. Within a year [[sea bird]]s had found the lake and more than 70 species have been spotted by the lake since, as a sign in the northern end of the lake knowns to tell. Footpaths and outlooks have been created around the lake since.<ref name="Hasselblad" />
== Birds == [[File:Isbladskärret 09 070607.JPG|thumb|A family of barnacle geese.]] [[File:Kaknästornet Rosenhill (Isbladskärret Blockhusudden) Stockholm Sweden 20050812.JPG|thumb|View from [[Kaknästornet]], Isbladskärret is in the center background.]] The large number of bird species have made the lake and the surrounding area popular among Stockholmers and tourists alike. The lake area is mostly famous for its colony of more than 100 [[heron]]s (all originating from birds that once escaped from the zoo at [[Skansen]]), but the surrounding walks in the forests are also known for the [[tawny owl]] found there.<ref name="WWF">{{cite web | title = Upptäck Ekoparken | pages = 12–13 | publisher = [[World Wide Fund for Nature]] | date = 2006-02-05 | location = Solna | url = http://www.wwf.se/source.php/1003300/wwf-1017732.pdf | accessdate = 2007-01-31 }}</ref>
Bird species with an annual presences by the lake include: [[Great crested grebe]], [[Slavonian grebe]], [[black-headed gull]], [[tufted duck]], [[gadwall]], [[northern shoveler]], [[wigeon]], [[Eurasian coot]], [[common moorhen]], [[common goldeneye]], ''[[Ardea (genus)|Ardea]]'', [[greylag goose]], [[Canada goose]], [[barnacle goose]], [[wood warbler]], [[European pied flycatcher]], [[thrush nightingale]], [[Eurasian nuthatch]], [[common treecreeper]], [[European robin]], [[hawfinch]], [[willow warbler]]s, [[whitethroat]], [[common chaffinch]], [[blue tit]], [[European goldfinch]], [[great spotted woodpecker]], [[dunlin]], [[greenshank]], [[northern lapwing]], [[ruff (bird)|ruff]], and [[European green woodpecker]]. Less common are [[icterine warbler]], [[marsh warbler]], [[sedge warbler]], [[Eurasian wren]], and [[lesser spotted woodpecker]]. <ref>[http://web.telia.com/~u86638101/Isblad/isblad2.htm Storkyrkoskolans specialsida om Isbladskärret] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091101134059/http://web.telia.com/~u86638101/Isblad/isblad2.htm |date=2009-11-01 }}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== See also == * [[Geography of Stockholm]] * [[Lakes of Sweden]] * [[Royal National City Park]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Isbladskarret}} [[Category:Geography of Stockholm]] [[Category:Lakes of Stockholm County]] [[Category:Lakes in Djurgården]]

'''Kurowski''' ({{small|Polish pronunciation:}} {{IPAc-pl|k|u|'|r|o|f|s|k|i}}; feminine: '''Kurowska'''; plural: '''Kurowscy''') is a [[Polish surname]]. It comes from place names such as [[Kurowo (disambiguation)|Kurowo]] and [[Kurów (disambiguation)|Kurów]], which are derived from a Polish word for roosters. Noble families bearing the name used various coats of arms, including [[Kur coat of arms|Kur]], [[Kurowski coat of arms|Kurowski]], [[Lubicz coat of arms|Lubicz]], [[Prawdzic coat of arms|Prawdzic]], [[Strzemie coat of arms|Strzemie]], [[Ślepowron coat of arms|Ślepowron]], [[Srzeniawa coat of arms|Srzeniawa]], and [[Topór coat of arms|Topór]]. There are over 16,000 people with the surname in Poland. {| class="wikitable" ! Language !! Masculine !! page.title: List of ecoregions with high endemism

revision.text:
[[File:Peninsula Sandstone Fynbos - Cape Town 8.JPG|thumb|upright=1.5|The [[fynbos]] of the Cape region of [[South Africa]] contains many [[endemic]] species of flowering plant.]] This list is for '''ecoregions with high endemism'''. According to the [[World Wide Fund for Nature]], the following [[ecoregions]] have the highest percentage of [[endemism|endemic]] plants.
==Ecoregions==
* [[Fynbos]] ([[South Africa]])<ref>{{WWF ecoregion|id=at1202|name=Lowland fynbos and renosterveld |accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref> * [[Hawaiian tropical dry forests]] ([[United States]])<ref>{{WWF ecoregion|id=oc0202|name=Hawaii tropical dry forests |accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref> * [[Hawaiian tropical rainforests]] ([[United States]])<ref>{{WWF ecoregion|id=oc0106|name=Hawaii tropical moist forests |accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref> * [[Kwongan|Kwongan heathlands]] ([[Australia]])<ref>{{WWF ecoregion|id=aa1205|name=Swan Coastal Plain Scrub and Woodlands|accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref> * [[Madagascar dry deciduous forests]] ([[Madagascar]])<ref>{{WWF ecoregion|id=at0202|name=Madagascar dry deciduous forests|accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref> * [[Madagascar lowland forests]] ([[Madagascar]])<ref>{{WWF ecoregion|id=at0117|name=Madagascar lowland forests|accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref> * [[New Caledonia dry forests]] ([[New Caledonia]])<ref>{{WWF ecoregion|id=aa0202|name=New Caledonia dry forests |accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref> * [[New Caledonia rain forests]] ([[New Caledonia]])<ref>{{WWF ecoregion|id=aa0113|name=New Caledonia rain forests |accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref> * [[Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forests]] ([[Mexico]])<ref>{{WWF ecoregion|id=nt0308|name=Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forests|accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref> * [[Sierra Madre del Sur pine-oak forests]] ([[Mexico]])<ref>{{WWF ecoregion|id=nt0309|name=Sierra Madre del Sur pine-oak forests|accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref> * [[Luzon rainforest|Luzon montane rainforests]] ([[Philippines]])<ref>{{WWF ecoregion|id=im0122|name=Luzon montane rain forests|accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref> * [[Luzon rainforest]]s ([[Philippines]])<ref>{{WWF ecoregion|id=im0123|name=Luzon rain forests|accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref> * [[Luzon tropical pine forests]] ([[Philippines]])<ref>{{WWF ecoregion|id=im0302|name=Luzon tropical pine forests |accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref> * [[Mindanao montane rain forests]] ([[Philippines]])<ref>{{WWF ecoregion|id=im0128|name=Mindanao montane rain forests|accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref> * [[Mindanao-Eastern Visayas rain forests]] ([[Philippines]])<ref>{{WWF ecoregion|id=im0129|name=Mindanao-Eastern Visayas rain forests|accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref> * [[Palawan rain forests]] ([[Philippines]])<ref>{{WWF ecoregion|id=im0143|name=Palawan rain forests|accessdate=26 January 2010}}</ref>

page.title: List of indigenous names of Eastern Caribbean islands
List of international presidential trips made by Dmitry Medvedev

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Diplomatic visits by heads of state]] to [[Category:Lists of diplomatic visits by heads of state]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
[[File:Medvedev presidential international trips.png|thumb|500px|World map highlighting countries visited by Dmitry Medvedev during his presidency. {{legend|#a1a7ef|One visit}} {{legend|#737ce8|Two visits}} {{legend|#4f5ae3|Three visits}} {{legend|#2533dd|Four visits}} {{legend|#1a25ac|Five visits}} {{legend|#111976|Seven visits}} {{legend|#0a1053|Ten visits}} {{legend|#da0000|Russia}}]] This is a list of '''international trips made by [[Dmitry Medvedev]]''', during [[Presidency of Dmitry Medvedev|his presidency]], he made 102 international trips to different countries. {{Medvedev sidebar}} [[File:Dmitry Medvedev in Turkmenistan 4-5 July 2008-7.jpg|thumb|Medvedev in Turkmenistan in 2008.]]
== 2008 == [[File:BRIC leaders in 2008.jpg|thumb|right|[[BRIC]] leaders in 2008]] [[File:Dmitry Medvedev in Peru 24-25 November 2008-5.jpg|thumb|Medvedev with [[President of Peru]] [[Alan García Pérez]].]] [[File:Dmitry Medvedev with Muammar Gaddafi-2.jpg|thumb|Medvedev with [[Muammar Gaddafi]].]] * Kazakhstan 22—23 May — first official visit as President ([[Astana]]).<ref>[http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4551 Президент России]</ref><ref>[http://www.news.ntv.ru/132694/ Телекомпания НТВ. Официальный сайт | Новости НТВ | Первый государственный визит президента Медведева]</ref> * China 23—25 May — official visit to China.<ref>[http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4552 Президент России]</ref> * Germany 5 June — official visit to Germany ([[Berlin]]).<ref>[http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4553 Президент России]</ref><ref>{{cite web|date=5 June 2008 |url=http://lenta.ru/news/2008/06/05/medvedev/ |title=Медведев предложил Европе заключить пакт о безопасности |publisher=[[Lenta.ru]] |accessdate=2010-08-13 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66aQoKrzs?url=http://lenta.ru/news/2008/06/05/medvedev/ |archivedate=2012-04-01 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * Belarus 22 June — official visit to [[Brest, Belarus|Brest]].<ref>[http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4554 Президент России]</ref><ref>[http://news.tut.by/politics/111532.html TUT.BY | НОВОСТИ — Лукашенко и Медведев стратегически сближались на «святой земле» — Политика — 22.06.2008, 22:42]</ref> * Azerbaijan 3 July — Official visit to Azerbaijan.<ref>[http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4555 Президент России]</ref> * Turkmenistan 4 July — Official visit to Turkmenistan.<ref>[http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4556 Президент России]</ref> * Kazakhstan 5—6 July — official visit to Kazakhstan ([[Astana]]) part of CIS Summit.<ref>[http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4558 Президент России]</ref> * Japan 7—8 July — — official visit to Japan (Tokyo, [[Hokkaido]]) as part of [[G8]] Summit.<ref>[http://www.mofa.go.jp/policy/economy/summit/2008/index.html Hokkaido Toyako Summit — TOP]</ref> * Tajikistan 28—29 August — official visit to Tajikistan ([[Dushanbe]]), meeting with [[Shanghai Cooperation Organisation|SCO]] leaders.<ref>[http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4559 Президент России]</ref> * Kazakhstan 22 September — visit to Kazakhstan ([[Aktobe]]).<ref>[http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4560 Президент России]</ref> * France 8 October — Conference of world politics in France.<ref>[http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4561 Президент России]</ref> * Kyrgyzstan 9 October - Official visit to [[Bishkek]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kremlin.ru/events/president/trips/4562|title=Визит в Киргизию • Президент России|website=Президент России|language=ru|access-date=2017-08-09}}</ref> * Armenia 10 October - Official visit to Yerevan.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kremlin.ru/events/president/trips/4563|title=Официальный визит в Армению • Президент России|website=Президент России|language=ru|access-date=2017-08-09}}</ref> * France 13–14 November - Visit to Nice.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kremlin.ru/events/president/trips/4564|title=Визит во Францию. Саммит Россия – ЕС • Президент России|website=Президент России|language=ru|access-date=2017-08-09}}</ref> * US November 15–16 - official visit to Washington D.C <ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4565 The President of Russia</ref> [[File: Dmitry Medvedev and Hugo Chavez, 2008.jpg|thumb|[[Dmitry Medvedev]] and the President [[Venezuela]] [[Hugo Chavez]].]] * [[Peru]] November 24 - official visit to [[Lima]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4569 Russian President</ref> * [[Brazil]] November 25–26 - official visit to [[Rio de Janeiro]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4568 The President of Russia</ref> * [[Venezuela]] November 27 - official visit to [[Caracas]]. Medvedev became the first Russian president to visit Venezuela.<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4567</ref> * [[Cuba]] November 28 - visit to [[Havana]]. Met with [[Raul Castro]], and [[Fidel Castro]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4566</ref><ref>http: //www.lenta.ru/news/2008/11/28/castro/</ref> * [[India]] December 4–5 - official visit to [[New Delhi]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4572</ref> * Kazakhstan December 19 - visit to [[Kazakhstan]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4570</ref>
== 2009 == [[File:Dmitry Medvedev 1 April 2009-1.jpg|thumb|right|London, United Kingdom, 1 April 2009]] [[File:Dmitry Medvedev 2 April 2009-1.jpg|thumb|G20 Summit, London, United Kingdom, 2 April 2009]] [[File:G8 Summit - 8 July 2009-9.jpg|thumb|G8, Italy, 8 July 2009]] * [[Uzbekistan]] January 22–23 - official visit to [[Tashkent]] and [[Samarkand]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4571</ref> * [[Italy]] March 1 - official visit to [[Bari]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4573 The President of Russia</ref> * [[Spain]] March 2–3 - official visit to [[Madrid]] <ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4574</ref> Medvedev was handed the key to Madrid.<ref>http: //lenta.ru/news/2009/03/02/key</ref> * [[Germany]] March 31 - visit to [[Berlin]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4575</ref> * [[Great Britain]] 1–2 April - official visit to [[London]]. attended the [[G20]] summit. * [[Finland]] April 20–21 - state visit to [[Helsinki]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/4576</ref> * [[Netherlands]] June 19–20 - official visit to [[Amsterdam]] * [[Egypt]] June 23–24 - visit to [[Cairo]]. * [[Nigeria]] June 24 - official visit [[Abuja]]<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/events/president/trips/4892</ref> * [[Namibia]] June 25–26 - official visit to [[Windhoek]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/events/president/trips/4896</ref> * [[Angola]] June 26 - official visit to [[Luanda]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/events/president/trips/4897</ref> * [[Azerbaijan]] June 29 - working visit to [[Baku]] * [[Italy]] 8–10 July - official visit * [[South Ossetia]] July 13 - working visit to [[South Ossetia]]. * [[Tajikistan]] July 30–31 - official visit to Dushanbe. Met with [[Asif Ali Zardari]], [[Emomali Rahmon]], and [[Hamid Karzai]] * [[Kyrgyzstan]] July 31-August 1 - official visit to ([[Cholpon-Ata]]). Attended the [[CSTO]] summit. * [[Mongolia]] 25–26 August - official visit to [[Mongolia]]. Attended the celebrations of the 70th anniversary of the [[Battle of Khalkhin-Gol]]. * [[Kazakhstan]] 11–12 September - working visit to [[Kazakhstan]], attended an informal meeting of the Presidents of [[Russia]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Kazakhstan]] and [[Turkmenistan]] in [[Aktau]]. * [[Turkmenistan]] September 13 - Attended the [[Silk Way Rally]] in [[Türkmenbaşy, Turkmenistan|Turkmenbashi]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/5456</ref> * [[Switzerland]] September 21–22 - the first visit by a russiab leader to Switzerland. He visited [[Kerzat]], [[Bern]], and [[Andermat]].<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/5542</ref> * [[United States]] September 27–28 – Official Visit to [[New York City]], United States to participate in 64th Regular Session of the United Nations General Assembly. Attended the G20 summit in [[Pittsburgh]]. [[File:Dmitry Medvedev in Chisinau 9 October 2009-1.jpg|thumb|Medvedev in Chisinau, 9 October 2009.]] * [[Moldova]] October 8–9 - Attended the CIS summit. * [[Kazakhstan]] October 16 - visit to [[Astana]]. Attended the final stage of the “Cooperation 2009” military exercises conducted by the [[Collective Rapid Reaction Force]] of the [[CSTO]] at the Maribulak military training field. of the final phase of the exercises. * [[Serbia]] October 21 - Official visit to Belgrade, Serbia. 65th anniversary of the liberation of Belgrade.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/events/president/trips/5789</ref> * [[Germany]] November 9 - working visit to [[Germany]]. Attended the celebrations in honor of the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall. * [[Singapore]] November 15–16 - official visit to [[Singapore]]. Attended the [[APEC]]. * [[Sweden]] November 18 - Working Visit * [[Belarus]] November 27 - Working Visit. * [[Italy]] December 3 - Working Visit to [[Italy]] and the [[Vatican City|Vatican]] * [[Denmark]] December 18 - Attended the UN Summit on Global Climate Change. * [[Kazakhstan]] December 19 - Working Visit to [[Almaty]]. * [[Turkmenistan]] December 22 - Working Visit to [[Ashgabat]].
== 2010 == [[File:Obama and Medvedev sign New START.jpg|thumb|right|Czech Republic, 8 April 2010]] [[File:Dmitry Medvedev in Poland 6 December 2010-2.jpeg|thumb|Medvedev in Poland in 2010.]]
* France 1–2 March - Visit to Paris.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/7012</ref> * Slovakia 6–7 April - Visit to Bratislava.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/7383</ref> * Czech Republic 7–8 April - Visit to Prague.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/7402</ref> Attended the signing of the Russian-American Treaty on the reduction and limitation of strategic offensive arms. * United States 13–14 April - Attend the Nuclear Security Summit. * Argentina 15–16 April - Visit to Bratislava.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/7463</ref> * Brazil 16–18 April - Visit to Brasilia.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/7482</ref> * Poland 18–21 April - Visit to Warsaw. * Ukraine 21–26 April - Visit to Kharkov.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/7520</ref> * Norway 26–27 April - Visit to Oslo.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/7564</ref> * Denmark 27–28 April - Visit to Copenhagen. * Syria 10–11 May - Visit to Damascus.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/7712</ref> * Turkey 12 May - Visit to Ankara.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/7731</ref> * Ukraine 18 May - Visit to Kiev.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/7787</ref> * Germany 5 June - Visit to Berlin <ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/7974</ref> * Uzbekistan 10–11 June - Visit to Tashkent.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/8022</ref> Attended the SCO Summit. * US 23–25 June - Visit to San Francisco. Met with the [[Governor of California]] [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]]<ref>http: //kremlin.ru/news/8145</ref> He also visited [[Stanford University]] <ref>http: //kremlin.ru/news/8154</ref> Met with [[Barack Obama]] in [[Washington, DC]]<ref>http://kremlin.ru/news/8166</ref> * Canada 25–27 June - Visit to Toronto. Attended the G8 and the G20.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/8175</ref> * Kazakhstan 5 July - Working visit.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/8279</ref> * Finland 21 July - Working visit.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/8397</ref> * [[Italy]] 23 July - official visit to [[Milan]].<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/8427</ref> * [[Abkhazia]] August 8 - working visit to [[Sukhumi]] and [[Gudauta]].<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/8599</ref> * Armenia 20 August - Official visit to Yerevan.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/news/8694</ref> * [[Azerbaijan]] 2–3 September - official visit to [[Baku]]<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/8823</ref> * Kazakhstan 7 September - Working visit.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/8845</ref> * China 26–28 September - Official visit.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/9071</ref> * Algeria 6 October - Official visit.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/9167</ref> * Cyprus 7 October - Official visit.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/9189</ref> * France 18–19 October - Visit to Deauville.<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/events/president/trips/4564</ref> * Vietnam 30–31 October - Working visit.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/9387</ref> Attended the ASEAN summit in Hanoi * [[South Korea]] November 10–12 - Attended the G20 Summit in [[Seoul]] <ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/9479</ref> * [[Japan]] November 10–12 - Attended the APEC Summit in [[Yokohama]] <ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/9506</ref> * [[Azerbaijan]] 18 November - working visit to [[Baku]]. Attended the Third Caspian Summit.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/news/9543</ref> * [[Portugal]] November 30 - Attended the Russia-Nato Summit in [[Lisbon]] <ref>http://kremlin.ru/news/9568</ref> * Kazakhstan 1 December - Working visit.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/9656</ref> * Poland 6 December - Working visit.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/9728</ref> * Belgium 7–8 December - Visit to Brussels.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/9732</ref> * India 20–21 December - Working visit.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/9869</ref>
== 2011 == [[File:Family photo - 2011 G8 Summit.jpeg|thumb|G8 Summit, France]] [[File:Dmitry Medvedev in Ukraine, October 2011-2.jpeg|thumb|Medvedev in Ukraine, October 2011.]] * [[State of Palestine|Palestine]] January 18 - official visit to [[Jericho]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/10092</ref> * [[Jordan]] January 19 - official visit to [[Amman]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/10098</ref> * [[China]] April 13–17 - Attended the BRICS summit in [[Hong Kong]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/10919</ref> * [[France]] May 26–27 - Attended the G8 summit in [[Deauville]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/11373</ref> * [[Italy]] 1–2 June - Working visit.<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/11439 The President of Russia</ref> * [[Uzbekistan]] June 14 - Working visit to [[Tashkent]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/11565</ref> * Kazakhstan 14—15 June - Working visit.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/events/president/trips/11581</ref> * [[Germany]] 18–19 July - visit to [[Hanover]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/12025</ref> * Kazakhstan 12 August - Working visit. Attended the CSTO summit<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/12376</ref> * Tajikistan 2—3 September — official visit to Tajikistan ([[Dushanbe]]), meeting with [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]] leaders.<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/12556</ref> * Ukraine 18 October - Working visit to Donetsk.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/13104</ref> * France 3–4 November — G20 summit in [[Cannes]].<ref>[http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/13331]</ref> * [[Germany]] 7–8 November - Official Visit.<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/13436</ref> * US November 15–16 - Attended the APEC summit in [[Hawaii]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/13515</ref> * Czech Republic 7–8 December - Visit to Prague.<ref>http://kremlin.ru/visits/13923</ref> * Belgium December 15 - Attended the Russia-EU summit in [[Brussels]].<ref>http://www.kremlin.ru/visits/14013</ref>
== 2012 == [[File:2012 BRICS Summit.jpg|thumb|BRICS, [[India]], 29 March 2012]] [[File:Dmitry Medvedev in South Korea, March 2012-1.jpeg|thumb|Medvedev in South Korea, March 2012.]]
* [[South Korea]] March 26–27 - Attended the 2012 [[Nuclear Security Summit]] in [[Seoul]].<ref>http://news.kremlin.ru/visits/14860</ref> * [[India]] March 28–30 - Participated in the [[BRICS]] Summit in [[New Delhi]].<ref>http://news.kremlin.ru/visits / 14872 Medvedev took part in the BRICS summit</ref>
==See also== *[[List of international presidential trips made by Vladimir Putin]] *[[List of international presidential trips made by Boris Yeltsin]]
