{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox military structure |name = Sohae Satellite Launching Station |native_name = 서해위성발사장 |location = North Korea |map_type = North Korea |coordinates = {{coord|39.660|124.705|type:landmark|display=inline}} |type = [[Spaceport]] |image = North Korean Unha-3 rocket at launch pad.jpg |image_size = 230px |caption = Unha-3 rocket in the site before launch of [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3]]. |built = {{Start date|1990s}} |builder = North Korea |status = {{font color|red|Inactive}} }} '''Sohae Satellite Launching Station''' ({{korean|hangul=서해위성발사장|hanja=西海衛星發射場|mr=Sohae Wisŏng Palsajang|context=north}}, also known as '''Tongch'ang-dong Space Launch Center''' and '''Pongdong-ri''') is a rocket launching site in [[Cholsan|Cholsan County]], [[North Pyongan]] Province, [[North Korea]]. The base is located among hills close to the northern border with [[China]]. The spaceport was built on the site of the village Pongdong-ri which was displaced during construction. It was the site for the 13 April 2012 launch of the North Korean satellite [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3]], which was launched to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the birth of [[Kim Il-Sung]].<ref name="naenara"/><ref name="dprk"/> The rocket launch failed, but on 12 December of the same year [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 Unit 2]] was successfully launched and brought into Earth orbit.
The launches were controversial as they were dismissed by the US as tests of [[ballistic missile]] technology and hence of breach of an agreement made between North Korea and the USA in February 2012.<ref name="dprk2"/>
During the [[2018 North Korea–United States summit]], Kim Jong-un promised that North Korea would destroy a missile engine test stand soon. The site was not initially named but was later identified to be the Sohae Satellite Launching Ground by US officials.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Spetalnick |first1=Matt |title=U.S. identifies North Korea missile test site it says Kim committed... |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-usa-site/u-s-identifies-north-korea-missile-test-site-it-says-kim-committed-to-destroy-idUSKBN1JH02B |website=Reuters |accessdate=21 June 2018}}</ref> This pledge was made official as part of the Pyongyang Declaration which Kim and South Korean leader Moon Jae-In signed at the [[September_2018_inter-Korean_summit#September_19_(Day_2)|September 2018 inter-Korean summit]].<ref>https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2018/09/19/kim-jong-un-moon-jae-sign-agreement-peace/1355006002/</ref>
==History== Signs of construction were visible during the early 1990s and became more pronounced by the early 2000s. A major progress in the construction was discovered in 2008 by [[Jane's Information Group]], which requested imagery from the satellite company [[DigitalGlobe]]. Movements from the Sanum’dong missile research factory with the erector transporter and railroad, road transportation to the space center of a prototype [[Unha-3]] class booster first two stages initially took place over 29–31 May 2009 possibly for logistics testing as well as personnel facilities infrastructure testing training purposes. The results of those tests suggest that military and design specialists ultimately decided to build a facilities access railroad to cut down the 15 kilometer road access logistics issues to the space center.
By early 2011 it was reported that the construction was completed and that it had been under construction for a decade.<ref name="reuters"/> The first official mention of the site took place in March 2012 when North Korea announced it will launch from that site the satellite [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3]]. On April 2012, prior to the launch of the satellite, Jang Myong-jin, director of the Sohae, introduced the launching process of the [[Unha-3]] rocket (Korean: 은하-3호, 銀河-3) during a guided media tour.<ref name="mail"/><ref name="naenara2"/>
The first launch of Kwangmyongsong-3 on 12 April 2012 failed. On 1 December 2012, the Korean Central News Agency announced that a [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 Unit 2|second version]] of Kwangmyongsong-3 was to be launched from Sohae between 10–22 December 2012.<ref name="zarya-32"/> North Korea declared the launch successful, and the South Korean military and [[North American Aerospace Defense Command]] (NORAD) reported that initial indications suggested that an object had achieved orbit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/50167891/ns/technology_and_science-space/|title=North Korea reports successful launch of controversial rocket|publisher=MSN/NBC}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norad.mil/News/2012/121112b.html |title=NORAD acknowledges missile launch |publisher=North American Aerospace Defense Command |date=11 December 2012 |accessdate=12 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121214134546/http://www.norad.mil/News/2012/121112b.html |archivedate=14 December 2012 |df= }}</ref> North Korea had previously claimed the [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-1]] and [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-2]] launches successful,<ref>{{cite web|last=Encyclopedia Astronautica|title=1998.08.31 - Kwangmyŏngsŏng 1|url=http://www.astronautix.com/details/kwa11163.htm|accessdate=15 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=N.Korea says it successfully launched satellite|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2009/04/05/idUKSEO88417|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=15 December 2012}}</ref> despite American military sources confirming that they failed to achieve orbit.<ref>{{cite web|last=United States Northern Command|title=NORAD and USNORTHCOM monitor North Korean launch|url=http://www.northcom.mil/News/2009/040509.html|accessdate=15 December 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017015121/http://www.northcom.mil/News/2009/040509.html|archivedate=17 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=North Korea space launch 'fails'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7984254.stm|publisher=BBC|accessdate=15 December 2012}}</ref>
On 7 February 2016, North Korea successfully launched a long-range rocket, carrying the satellite [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-4|Kwangmyongsong-4]], from the station.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = DPRK announces successful launch of Kwangmyongsong-4 satellite - CCTV News - CCTV.com English|url = http://english.cntv.cn/2016/02/07/ARTI98lx135UGjmMIJwXw1FB160207.shtml|website = english.cntv.cn|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref> Critics suggest that the real purpose of the launch was test a [[ballistic missile]]. The launch was strongly condemned by the [[United Nations Security Council|UN Security Council.]]<ref>{{Cite web|title = UN Security Council vows new sanctions after N Korea's rocket launch|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-35518058|website = BBC News|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = U.N. Security Council condemns North Korea launch - CNN.com|url = http://www.cnn.com/2016/02/07/asia/north-korea-rocket-launch-window/index.html|website = CNN|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title = North Korea rocket launch: UN security council condemns latest violation|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/feb/07/north-korea-launches-long-range-rocket-it-claims-is-carrying-a-satellite|newspaper = The Guardian|date = 2016-02-07|access-date = 2016-02-07|issn = 0261-3077|language = en-GB|first = Justin McCurry Damien|last = Gayle|last2 = agencies}}</ref> A statement broadcast on [[Korean Central Television]] said that a new Earth observation satellite, Kwangmyongsong-4, had successfully been put into orbit less than 10 minutes after lift-off from the Sohae space centre in [[North Pyongan Province|North Phyongan province]].<ref name=":0" /> North Korea's [[National Aerospace Development Administration]] stated the launch was "an epochal event in developing the country's science, technology, economy and defence capability by legitimately exercising the right to use space for independent and peaceful purposes".<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = North Korean rocket puts object into space, angers neighbours, U.S.|url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-northkorea-satellite-idUKKCN0VG00L|website = Reuters UK|access-date = 2016-02-07|language = en-GB}}</ref> The launch prompted South Korea and the United States to discuss the possibility of placing an advanced missile defence system in South Korea,<ref>{{Cite web|title = China worried over US-South Korea plans to deploy THAAD missile system - The Economic Times|url = http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/china-worried-over-us-south-korea-plans-to-deploy-thaad-missile-system/articleshow/50892130.cms|website = The Economic Times|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Korea says THAAD 'helpful' to security|url = http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/01/205_196787.html|website = koreatimes|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref> a move strongly opposed by both China and Russia.<ref name=":1" />
==Facilities==
The entire facility occupies over six square kilometers, and consists of a launch site, a static rocket motor test stand, vehicle checkout and processing buildings, a launch control building, a large support area, a complex headquarters building and an entry control point. The site is five times larger than Tonghae Launch Site.<ref name="kherald"/> There is much speculation about the functions of different parts of the site <ref name="msnbc"/> but the nuances of satellite photography based guesswork may not be communicated effectively in the mass media.
Western sources identified a building as a "high bay processing facility" which turned out to be the launch control centre when the site was visited by journalists. The building previously identified as the control centre was actually an observation point.<ref name="msnbc"/>
==Dismantlement and International Inspection== In July 2018, North Korea began dismantling the Sohae Satellite Launching Station.<ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2018/07/23/north-korea-begins-dismantling-key-test-site-satellite-imagery-suggests/?utm_term=.185bd31ee091</ref> Satellite images taken between July 20 and 22 showed the destruction of a rocket engine test stand used to develop liquid-fuel engines for ballistic missiles, space-launch vehicles and a rail-mounted processing building where space launch vehicles were assembled before being moved to the launch pad<ref>https://www.cbsnews.com/news/north-korea-dismantling-sohae-satellite-launch-site-38-north-denuclearization/</ref> Commercial satellite imagery from August 3, 2018 confirmed that additional dismantlement activities were taking place at Sohae as well, including the destruction of facility's vertical engine test stand and fuel/oxidizer bunkers.<ref>https://www.38north.org/2018/08/sohae080718/</ref> In September 2018, North Korean leader Kim Jung-Un and South Korean leader Moon Jae-In signed the "Pyongyang Joint Declaration of September 2018", which, among other things, pledged for North Korea to complete its dismantlement of Sohae and allow foreign experts to observe the dismantling of the missile engine testing site and a launch pad.<ref name=oct31observer>https://www.cnbc.com/2018/10/31/north-korea-reportedly-readies-nuclear-missile-sites-for-inspectors.html</ref> By October 10, 2018, commercial satellite imagery confirmed that the site's legacy fuel/oxidizer bunker located at the launch pad had been largely removed.<ref>https://www.38north.org/2018/10/sohae101018/</ref> Officials from South Korea's National Intelligence Service who visited the site on October 31, 2018 stated that Sohae was in fact being dismantled and was ready for an upcoming international inspection.<ref name=oct31observer />
==See also== *[[Tonghae Satellite Launching Ground]] *[[Punggye-ri Nuclear Test Site]]
==References== <references> <ref name="reuters">{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/17/us-korea-north-missile-idUSTRE71G0CX20110217 |title=North Korea completes second missile site |first=Jeremy |last=Laurence|date=17 February 2011|publisher=[[Reuters]] |accessdate=11 April 2012}}</ref>
<ref name="mail">{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2126900/North-Korea-moves-step-closer-firing-long-range-missile-insists-launch-satellite-survey-countryside.html |title=Fears North Korea are preparing to carry out a new underground nuclear test|first1=Emily |last1=Allen|first2=Rob|last2=Cooper|date=10 April 2012|publisher=[[Daily Mail]] |accessdate=12 April 2012}}</ref>
<ref name="kherald">{{cite web |url=http://ph.news.yahoo.com/n-korea-finishes-missile-facility-reports-20110411-033003-658.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130105143133/http://ph.news.yahoo.com/n-korea-finishes-missile-facility-reports-20110411-033003-658.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 January 2013 |title=N. Korea finishes new missile facility: reports |author=Song Hang-So |date=11 April 2011 |publisher=[[The Korea Herald]] |accessdate=11 April 2012 }}</ref>
<!--ref name="nktech">{{cite web |url=http://www.northkoreatech.org/2012/03/27/inside-sohae-launch-facility/ |title=Inside Sohae Launch Facility |first=Martyn |last=Williams|date=27 March 2012 |publisher= North Korea Tech|accessdate=11 April 2012}}</ref-->
<!--ref name="time">{{cite web |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2110807,00.html#ixzz1qtCvzxuI |title=Images Show North Korea Launch Work |author=Foster Klug |date=1 April 2012 |work= |publisher=[[Time Magazine]] |accessdate=11 April 2012}}</ref-->
<!--ref name="nktech2">{{cite web |url=http://www.northkoreatech.org/2012/04/12/latest-satellite-images-of-sohae-launch-facility/ |title=Latest satellite images of Sohae launch facility |first=Martyn |last=Williams|date=12 April 2012 |publisher= North Korea Tech|accessdate=12 April 2012}}</ref-->
<ref name="naenara">{{cite web |url=http://naenara.com.kp/en/news/news_view.php?19+4425 |title=DPRK to Launch Application Satellite |date=17 March 2012 |publisher= [[Naenara Times]]|accessdate=12 April 2012}}</ref>
<ref name="naenara2">{{cite web |url=http://naenara.com.kp/en/news/news_view.php?26+7383|title=Foreign Media Persons and Experts on Space Science and Technology Visit Sohae Satellite Launching Station |date=9 April 2012 |publisher= [[Naenara Times]]|accessdate=12 April 2012}}</ref>
<!--ref name="38N">{{cite web |url=http://38north.org/2012/04/tongchang0405/|title=Is the Rocket on the Sohae Launch Pad? A 38 North Exclusive |date=6 April 2012 |publisher= [[38 North]], [[Johns Hopkins University]]|accessdate=12 April 2012}}</ref-->
<ref name="dprk">{{cite web |url=http://vtncankor.wordpress.com/2012/03/29/dprk-foreign-ministry-kwangmyongsong-3-ready-to-launch/|title=Kwangmyongsong-3 Ready to Launch |date=29 March 2012 |publisher= Korean Committee of Solidarity with the World People|accessdate=12 April 2012}}</ref>
<ref name="dprk2">{{cite web |url=http://vtncankor.wordpress.com/2012/03/20/dprks-satellite-launch-not-contradictory-to-dprk-u-s-agreement-kcna/|title=DPRK’s Satellite Launch Not Contradictory to DPRK-U.S. Agreement — KCNA |date=20 March 2012 |publisher= Korean Central News Agency|accessdate=12 April 2012}}</ref>
<ref name="msnbc">{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/46995113/ns/technology_and_science-space/#.T4YvCI6H31t|title=Clues about North Korea's space plans come to light at last |date=9 April 2012 |publisher= [[MSNBC]]|first=James |last=Oberg|accessdate=12 April 2012}}</ref>
<ref name="zarya-32">{{cite web|url=http://www.zarya.info/Gallimaufry/Kwangmyongsong32.php|title=Kwangmyongsong 3-2 Launch|date=1 December 2012|publisher=Zarya.info|first=Robert|last=Christy|accessdate=1 December 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130108073955/http://www.zarya.info/Gallimaufry/Kwangmyongsong32.php|archivedate=8 January 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
</references>

revision.text:
In Judaism, Christianity and Islam, the '''Third Heaven''' is a division of [[Heaven]] in [[religious cosmology]]. In some traditions it is considered the [[Throne of God|abode of God]],<ref name="mthen">Henry, Matthew, [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/henry/mhc6.viii.xiii.html ''Commentary on the Whole Bible Volume VI (Acts to Revelation)'': Second Corinthians Chap. XII] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060825122614/http://www.ccel.org/ccel/henry/mhc6.viii.xiii.html |date=2006-08-25 }}, Public domain, Library of Congress call no: BS490.H4, at [http://www.ccel.org/ Christian Classics Ethereal Library]</ref> and in others a lower level of [[Paradise]], commonly [[Seven Heavens|one of seven]].<ref name = "lj">Ginzberg, Louis (1909) [http://www.sacred-texts.com/jud/loj/loj103.htm ''The Legends of the Jews''], Chapter 1, at [http://www.sacred-texts.com/index.htm sacred-texts.com]</ref>
==Judaism== The early books of the [[Tanakh]] reference [[Heaven]] (Heb. ''[[Heaven in Judaism|Shamayim]]''), but not a Third Heaven or a specific number of heavens.<ref name="mthen"/> Heaven is mentioned several times in the first chapter of [[Book of Genesis|Genesis]]. It appears in the first verse as a creation of God. His dividing the light from the darkness in verses 4 and 5 this has been interpreted as the separation of heaven into two sections: day (God's throne) and night (where our universe is contained). In verse 8 heaven refers to the atmosphere over the earth in which birds fly, and in verse 14 it's the setting for the celestial lights, later identified (verse 16) as the [[sun]], [[moon]] and [[star]]s.<ref>See a good Commentary on Youtube (Ruckman, Andrew Gen. 1 part 1)</ref>
A third concept of Heaven, also called ''shamayi h'shamayim'' (שׁמי השׁמים or "Heaven of Heavens"), is mentioned in such passages as [[Book of Genesis|Genesis]] 28:12, [[Deuteronomy]] 10:14 and [[Books of Kings|1 Kings]] 8:27 as a distinctly spiritual realm containing (or being traveled by) [[angel]]s and God.<ref>van der Toorn, Becking, van der Horst (1999), ''Dictionary of Deities and Demons in The Bible'', Second Extensively Revised Edition, Entry: ''Heaven'', pp. 388–390, William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company, {{ISBN|0-8028-2491-9}}</ref>
The ambiguity of the term ''shamayim'' in the Hebrew Bible, and the fact that it's a plural word, give "heavens" various interpretations regarding its nature, notably the [[Elijah#Ascension into the heavens|ascension of the prophet Elijah]].
In the non-canonical [[Second Book of Enoch]], Third Heaven is described as a location "between corruptibility and incorruptibility" containing the [[Tree of Life (Judeo-Christian)|Tree of Life]], "whereon the Lord rests, when he goes up into paradise." (chapter 8) Two springs in the Third Heaven, one of milk and the other of honey, along with two others of wine and oil, flow down into the [[Garden of Eden]]. (verse 6) In contrast with the common concept of [[Paradise]], the [[Second Book of Enoch]] also describes it as "a very terrible place" for those who do wrong, with "all manner of tortures" inflicted by merciless angels on "those who dishonour God, who on earth practice sin against nature," including [[Sodomy|sodomites]], [[Magic (paranormal)|sorcerers]], [[Incantation|enchanters]], [[Witchcraft|witches]], the proud, thieves, liars and those guilty of various other transgressions. (chapter 10)
In the [[Slavic languages|Slavonic]] version of the ''Greek Apocalypse of Baruch'', also known as [[3 Baruch]], the author is shown a [[Phoenix (mythology)|phoenix]], and a [[dragon]] residing there is said to eat the bodies of "those that have spent their lives in evil."<ref>[http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=329&letter=B Baruch, Apocalypse of] at [http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/ jewishencyclopedia.com]</ref>
In ''The Legends of the Jews'' by [[Louis Ginzberg]], this third division of Paradise is said to be, like the other six, "twelve myriads of miles in width and twelve myriads of miles in length," built of silver and gold, and containing "the best of everything there is in heaven."<ref name="lj"/>
===Residents=== Aside from the redeemed, the transgressors and various angels mentioned in the Bible and other Hebrew literature, a number of specific figures and spirits are mentioned as residing in the Third Heaven. According to ''The [[Legends of the Jews]]'' by [[Louis Ginzberg]] these include:<ref name = "lj"/> * [[Abraham]] * [[Isaac]] * [[Jacob]] * [[Moses]] * [[Aaron]] * [[Azrael]] * the [[Israelite]]s of the [[The Exodus|Exodus]] * the kings of [[Kingdom of Judah|Judah]] (notably [[David]], but "with the exception of [[Manasseh of Judah|Manasseh]], the son of [[Hezekiah]], who presides in the second division, over the penitents")
==Christianity==
===New Testament=== In [[2 Corinthians]] [[Paul the Apostle]] writes, "I know a person in Christ who fourteen years ago was caught up to the third heaven—whether in the body or out of the body I do not know; God knows. And I know that such a person—whether in the body or out of the body I do not know; God knows—was caught up into Paradise and heard things that are not to be told, that no mortal is permitted to repeat."<ref>{{bibleref2|2 Corinthians|12:2–4}}</ref> According to [[E. W. Bullinger]], the Greek says "caught away", not "caught up" possibly reflecting Jewish beliefs that Paradise was somewhere other than the uppermost heaven.<ref>[[E. W. Bullinger]] A Critical Lexicon and Concordance to the English and Greek "2, 14, To this "Third heaven" and " Paradise " Paul was caught away, 2 Cor. xii. 2, 4, (not " up," see under " catch,") in "visions and revelations of the Lord," 2 Cor. xii. 1. One catching away – with a double revelation of the New heaven and the ..."</ref>
Ideas about [[Religious cosmology|the system of "heavens"]] held by Jews and Christians in first-century communities are also evident in the non-canonical [[Second Book of Enoch]] (see previous section).
===New Testament apocrypha=== According to the ''[[First Apocalypse of James|Apocalypse of James]]'',<ref name = "da">Davidson, Gustav (1967), ''[https://books.google.com/books/about/A_dictionary_of_angels.html?id=Ed7yHWuTEewC A Dictionary of Angels, Including The Fallen Angels]'', Entry: '''Third Heaven''', Free Press, p. 288, Library of Congress Catalog Card Number: 66-19757, {{ISBN|9780029070505}}</ref> John the Baptist dwells in the Third Heaven.
==Islam== According to [[Islam]]ic tradition, [[Muhammad]]'s [[Isra and Miraj|Mi'raj]] (ascension through the heavens) included an admission to the Third Heaven by the angel [[Gabriel]], in which he met [[Joseph (Hebrew Bible)|Joseph]], who received him warmly.<ref>[http://muslim-canada.org/miraj_dictionaryofislam.html Mi'raj] at the [http://muslim-canada.org/ Canadian Society of Muslims Website]</ref> Islamic tradition also places [[Azrael]], the angel of death, in the Third Heaven.<ref name="da"/> The third heaven is depicted as being constructed of pearl and/or other luminous metals.
According to [[Shia Islam|Shi'ite]] sources, the Third Heaven is named '''''Marum''''' ({{lang-ar|ماروم}}).<ref>{{cite book|title=Al-Burhan fi Tafsir al-Qur'an|location=V. 5|pages=415}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Empyrean]] * [[Seven Heavens]] * [[Vídbláin]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.crivoice.org/thirdheaven.html What is the "third heaven"], Douglas Ward, 2006 at ''The Voice'' * [http://www.blueletterbible.org/kjv/2Cr/2Cr012.html#top 2 Corinthians, Chapter 12] ([[King James Version of the Bible|KJV]])
[[Category:Jewish mysticism]] [[Category:Christian cosmology]] [[Category:Christian terminology]] [[Category:Heaven]] [[Category:Afterlife places]] [[Category:Islamic cosmology]] [[Category:Islamic terminology]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox mountain pass | name = Wakhjir Pass | photo = Head of Ab-i-Panja Valley, Looking Towards Wakhjir Pass and Oxus Source Glaciers.jpg | photo_caption = Photo of the valley before the pass by [[Aurel Stein]] | elevation_m = 4923 | elevation_ref = | traversed = [[Pamir Mountains]] | map = Afghanistan | map_caption = Location in Afghanistan | location = [[Badakhshan Province]], [[Afghanistan]] [[Xinjiang]], [[China]] | range = [[Pamirs]] | coordinates = {{coord|37|05|14|N|74|29|03|E|type:pass|display=inline,title}} | topo = }} {{Chinese |s=瓦根基达坂 |t=瓦根基達坂 |p=wǎgēnjī dábǎn |s2=瓦赫吉尔山口 |t2=瓦赫吉爾山口 |p2=wǎhèjí'ěr shānkǒu |w2=wa<sup>3</sup>-ho<sup>4</sup>-chi<sup>2</sup>-erh<sup>3</sup> shan<sup>1</sup>-K'ou<sup>3</sup> |lang1=fa |lang1_content={{lang|fa|گذرگاه واخجیر|rtl=yes}} Gozargāh-e Vākhjīr }}
The '''Wakhjir Pass,'''<ref name=adamecp185>[[Ludwig W. Adamec]]. Historical and political gazetteer of Afghanistan Vol. 1. Badakhshan Province and northeastern Afghanistan. [[Graz]] : Akad. Druck- und Verl.-Anst., 1972.p. 185.</ref> also spelled '''Vakhjir Pass''', is a [[mountain pass]] in the [[Hindu Kush]] or [[Pamirs]] at the eastern end of the [[Wakhan Corridor]], the only pass between [[Afghanistan]] and [[China]]. It links [[Wakhan]] in Afghanistan with the [[Tashkurgan Tajik Autonomous County]] in [[Xinjiang]], China, at an altitude of {{convert|4923|m|ft}},<ref name="border_agreement"/> but the pass is not an official border crossing point. The border has the sharpest official change of clocks of any international frontier ([[UTC+4:30]] in Afghanistan to [[UTC+8]], [[Time in China|in China]]). China refers to the pass as ''South Wakhjir Pass'' ({{zh|c=南瓦根基达坂}}), as there is a northern pass on the Chinese side.<ref name="border_agreement">{{cite wikisource |title=中华人民共和国和阿富汗王国边界条约 |trans_title=China-Afghanistan Border Agreement |wslanguage=zh|quote=经过高程为4923米的南瓦根基达坂（阿方图称瓦根基山口）|date=1963-11-22}}</ref>
==Overview==
{{see also|Wakhan Corridor}}
There is no road across the pass. On the Chinese side, the immediate region is only accessible to military personnel.<ref name="juldu">{{Cite web | title = Pamir & Wakhan - Getting there | first = Julien | last = Dufour | work = Online Guide to Trekking in the Wakhan and Afghan Pamir | date = | accessdate = 2017-02-03 | url = http://www.juldu.com/Pamir/getting_there.html | language = | quote = }}</ref> A {{convert|92|km|mi}}- long barbed wire fence was erected on the border, and there is a Chinese border guard outpost at Keketuluke just {{convert|20|km|mi}} east of the pass.<ref name="chinadaily">{{Cite web | title = High alert | author = Cui Jia | website = [[China Daily]] | date = 2014-09-25 | accessdate = 2017-02-03 | url = http://usa.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2014-09/25/content_18657413.htm | language = en | quote = A barbed wire fence appeared after another 20 km west of Keketuluke. The fence separates China and Afghanistan amid the 92 km border area. }}</ref> In the summer of 2009, the [[Ministry of National Defense of the People's Republic of China|Chinese Ministry of National Defense]] began construction of a new road to within {{convert|10|km|mi}} of the border for use by border guards.<ref>{{Cite web | title = China Builds Closer Ties to Afghanistan through Wakhan Corridor | author = Russell Hsiao, Glen E. Howard | work = [[Jamestown Foundation]] | date = 2010-01-07 | accessdate = 2017-02-03 | url = https://jamestown.org/program/china-builds-closer-ties-to-afghanistan-through-wakhan-corridor/ | quote = }}</ref> The road leads through the [[Taghdumbash Pamir]] to the [[Karakoram Highway]] {{convert|80|km|mi}} away. The valley to the east of Wakhjir Pass on the Chinese side is called [[Chalachigu Valley]]. It is entirely closed to visitors; however, local residents and herders from the area are permitted access.<ref name="globaltimes">{{Cite web | title = 《环球时报》记者组在瓦罕走廊感受中国边防 | author = 环球时报 | website = china.huanqiu.com | publisher = [[Global Times]] | date = 2009-05-07 | accessdate = 2017-02-04 | url = http://china.huanqiu.com/roll/2009-05/453882.html | language = zh | quote = 由于瓦罕走廊没有开放旅游，普通游客走到这里便无法继续前行。...据他介绍，该派出所海拔3900米，辖区内户籍75户，约300人，到七八月夏季牧场开放时，山下牧民会到高海拔地区放牧，走廊人口将达到1800人左右。 }}</ref> The Chinese refers to it as the portion of Wakhan Corridor in China.
On the Afghan side, the nearest road is a rough road to [[Sarhad-e Wakhan]] (also known as Sarhad-e Broghil), about {{convert|100|km|mi}} from the pass by paths.<ref>[http://www.mockandoneil.com/stg04r3.htm#faizabad J. Mock and K. O'Neil (2004): Expedition Report]</ref> Just below the pass on the Afghan side is an ice cave, at an altitude of {{convert|4554|m|ft}}. This is the source of the Wakhjir River, which ultimately flows to the [[Amu Darya]] (Oxus). The cave is therefore claimed as a source of the Amu Darya. [[Dilisang Pass]], to Pakistan, is in the same valley about {{convert|20|km|mi}} away.<ref name="juldu"/>
==History== Wakhjir Pass is part of the [[Silk Road]]. It is believed that the famous Chinese Buddhist pilgrim [[Xuanzang]] traveled via this pass on his return trip to China in approximately [[649 AD]].<ref name="book_Unit">{{Cite magazine | last = Stein | first = M. Aurel | authorlink = Aurel Stein | title = Exploration in Chinese Turkestan | magazine = [[United States Congressional Serial Set]] | number = 748 | page = 752 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Neg3AQAAIAAJ&pg=PA752&dq=wakhjir+pass | publisher = [[Smithsonian Institution]] | location = Washington, D.C. | date = 1903-06-30 | accessdate = 2017-02-03 | language = | quote = }}</ref>
Traditionally, the pass is inaccessible for at least five months out of the year and is accessible irregularly for the remainder of the year.<ref name="silkroadstudies">{{Cite web | title = China and Afghan Opiates: China and Afghan Opiates: Assessing the Risk | first = Jacob | last = Townsend | website = Silk Road Paper | publisher = [[Institute for Security and Development Policy]] | date = June 2005 | accessdate = 2017-02-03 | url = https://www.silkroadstudies.org/resources/pdf/SilkRoadPapers/2005_06_SRP_Townsend_Opiates.pdf | language = | quote = The only border crossing is the Wakhjir Pass at an altitude of 4,927m, which is closed for at least five months a year and is open irregularly for the remainder. | page = 36 }}</ref> The terrain is extremely difficult, although [[Aurel Stein]] reported that the immediate approaches to the pass were "remarkably easy".<ref name=Stein>{{Cite book | last = Stein | first = M. Aurel | authorlink = Aurel Stein | title = Ancient Khotan: Detailed Report of Archaeological Explorations in Chinese Turkestan | publisher = [[Clarendon Press]] | year = 1907 | location = Oxford, UK | volume = vol. 1 | pages = 32 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=FaMMAQAAMAAJ&vq=remarkably%20easy&pg=PA32 | isbn = }}</ref> There are few records of successful crossings by foreigners. Historically the pass was a trading route between [[Badakhshan]] and [[Yarkant County|Yarkand]], used by merchants from [[Bajaor]].<ref name=Stein/> It appears that [[Marco Polo]] came this way, although he did not mention the pass by name. The Jesuit priest [[Benedict Goëz]] crossed from the Wakhan to China between 1602 and 1606. The next oldest accounts are from the period of [[the Great Game]] in the late 19th century.<ref>Shahrani, M. Nazif. (1979) ''The Kirghiz and Wakhi of Afghanistan: Adaptation to Closed Frontiers and War'' University of Washington Press, Seattle, {{ISBN|0-295-95669-0}}; 1st paperback edition with new preface and epilogue (2002), {{ISBN|0-295-98262-4}} p.27</ref> In 1868, a [[pundit (explorer)|pundit]] known as the Mirza, working for the [[Great Trigonometric Survey]] of [[India]], crossed the pass.<ref>Shahrani, M. Nazif. (1979 and 2002) p.31</ref> There were further crossings in 1874 by Captain [[Thomas Edward Gordon|T.E. Gordon]] of the British Army,<ref>Keay, J. (1983) ''When Men and Mountains Meet'' {{ISBN|0-7126-0196-1}} p. 256-7</ref> in 1891 by [[Francis Younghusband]],<ref>Younghusband, F. (1896, republished 2000) ''The Heart of a Continent'' {{ISBN|978-1-4212-6551-3}}</ref> and in 1894 by [[Lord Curzon]].<ref>''Geographical Journal'' (July to September 1896) cited in [http://www.mockandoneil.com/stg04app.htm Mock and O'Neil 2004 Shipton Tilman Grant Application]</ref> In May 1906 Sir Aurel Stein crossed, and reported that at that time the pass was used by only 100 pony loads of goods each way annually.<ref name="Shahrani, M. Nazif 2002 p.37">Shahrani, M. Nazif (1979 and 2002) p.37</ref> Since then the only Westerner to have crossed the pass seems to have been [[Bill Tilman|H.W. Tilman]] in 1947.<ref>[http://www.mockandoneil.com/stg04app.htm Mock and O'Neil 2004 Shipton Tilman Grant Application]</ref>
In 1895 the pass was established as the border between China and Afghanistan in an agreement between the British and the Russians, although the Chinese and Afghans did not finally agree on the border until 1963.<ref name="border_agreement"/><ref name="web._">{{Cite web | title = International Boundary Study - Afghanistan – China Boundary | author = Office of the Geographer | work = web.archive.org | date = 1969-05-01 | accessdate = 2017-02-03 | publisher = [[Bureau of Intelligence and Research]] | url = http://www.law.fsu.edu/library/collection/limitsinseas/IBS089.pdf | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150103225351/http://www.law.fsu.edu/library/collection/limitsinseas/IBS089.pdf | archive-date = 2015-01-03 | language = | quote = The Afghanistan–China boundary agreement, signed on November 22, 1963, was the fifth of these boundaries treaties initiated by the Chinese communists. }}</ref>
It is believed that in more recent times, the pass is sometimes used as a low-intensity drug smuggling route, and is used to transport opium made in Afghanistan to [[China]].<ref name="caravanistan">{{Cite web | title = Afghanistan border crossings | author = | work = Caravanistan | date = | accessdate = 2017-02-03 | url = http://caravanistan.com/border-crossings/afghanistan/ | quote = It is mostly used as a low-intensity drug-smuggling corridor to bring opium to China during the summer. }}</ref> Afghanistan has asked [[People's Republic of China|China]] on several occasions to open the border in the Wakhan Corridor for economic reasons or as an alternative supply route for fighting the [[Taliban insurgency]]. However, China has resisted, largely due to unrest in its far western province of [[Xinjiang]], which borders the corridor.<ref>[http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/003200906111512.htm Afghanistan tells China to open Wakhan corridor route]. ''[[The Hindu]]''. June 11, 2009 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110108051455/http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/003200906111512.htm |date=January 8, 2011 }}</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/8097933.stm China mulls Afghan border request]. [[BBC News Online]]. June 12, 2009</ref> {{as of|2009|12|alt=In December 2009}}, it was reported that the [[United States]] had asked China to open the corridor.<ref>[http://www.southasiaanalysis.org//papers36/paper3579.html South Asia Analysis Group: Paper No. 3579, 31 December 2009] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613093607/http://www.southasiaanalysis.org//papers36/paper3579.html |date=June 13, 2010 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
